Date: Elon Musk Wants All of Twitter
Title: Elon Musk, Twitter’s largest shareholder and biggest agitator, offered this morning to buy the rest of the social media company and take it private. His “best and final offer,” as he put it in a financial filing, is $54.20 a share, nearly 40 percent higher than Twitter’s stock price before the mercurial billionaire’s purchases became public.
Text: The Tesla chief executive made an offer worth more than $40 billion to buy Twitter and take it private.

Date: On Poland-Ukraine Border, the Past Is Always Present. It’s Not Always Predictive.
Title: On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.
Text: For a Jewish reporter with Eastern European roots, one of the hardest challenges covering the war is reconciling the horrors of the Holocaust with the Poland and Ukraine of today.

Date: As two U.S. lawmakers visit Kyiv, the trip’s organizer says he hopes more officials, and weapons, will follow.
Title: In a hastily organized show of support for Ukraine, Senator Steve Daines of Montana and Representative Victoria Spartz of Indiana traveled on Thursday to Kyiv and sites of rights abuses in the city’s suburbs, becoming the first American officials to turn up since the start of the war.
Text: Senator Steve Daines of Montana and Representative Victoria Spartz of Indiana, both Republicans, were invited by Ukraine’s government on short notice.

Date: Europe Reluctantly Readies Russian Oil Embargo
Title: European officials are drafting plans for an embargo on Russian oil products, the most contested measure yet to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine and a move long resisted because of its big costs for Germany and its potential to disrupt politics around the region and increase energy prices.
Text: Officials are drafting a phased import ban on Russian oil products, but the measure won’t be floated until after the second round of the French elections at the earliest.

Date: Wall Street Profits Slump as War Weighs on Outlook
Title: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has only clouded an already uncertain economic outlook, banking executives said this week as they reported sliding profits and growing concerns about the state of the recovery from the pandemic.
Text: Bank executives are lately taking a more somber tone than the ebullience of recent quarters, when banks recorded blockbuster earnings.

Date: Anna Netrebko, Shunned in Much of the West, to Sing in Monte Carlo
Title: Anna Netrebko, the superstar soprano whose international career crumbled after the invasion of Ukraine because of her past support of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, has been invited to sing in Monaco this month at the Opéra de Monte-Carlo.
Text: After Russia invaded Ukraine, the soprano lost work in the West because of her past support of President Vladimir V. Putin. She was invited to sing this month in Monaco.

Date: The Russian media dismisses photographic evidence of atrocities in Ukraine as ‘fake.’
Title: State television programs in Russia have not shied away from showing images of death and destruction in Ukraine. Viewers have seen corpses in the streets of Bucha, blasted-out cars at a train station in Kramatorsk and the remains of a hospital complex attacked in Mariupol.
Text: Russians are being shown some of the same distressing imagery from the war as the rest of the world, but with a big twist.

Date: Ukrainians Face New Hurdle at U.S. Border: No Dogs
Title: Natasha Hrytsenko, a lifelong resident of Ukraine, had always dreamed of having a fluffy white dog. When she started working, Ms. Hrytsenko, now 30, used her first two paychecks to buy a purebred mini Maltese puppy. She brought Eddie home to the Kyiv apartment that she shared with her older sister.
Text: Federal health guidelines limit the entry of pets from countries like Ukraine with a high incidence of rabies. For some refugees, the rule has been devastating.

Date: Moody’s warns that Russia’s bond payments in rubles could lead to default.
Title: Russia’s repayment of foreign currency bonds in rubles could be considered a default if it does not reverse course and pay in dollars, Moody’s, the ratings agency, said on Thursday.
Text: The failure to fulfill its foreign debt obligation would be the first in more than a century for Russia, dealing with sanctions after its invasion of Ukraine.

Date: Russia Hits Setbacks, as Flagship Sinks and E.U. Mulls Oil Ban
Title: Russia’s faltering war against Ukraine suffered a pair of setbacks Thursday when the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet sank after a catastrophic explosion and fire, as the European Union moved closer to an embargo on Russian oil imports.
Text: Ukraine said it hit a Russian warship in the Black Sea with its own missiles, a damaging blow to Moscow, symbolically and militarily, if its claim is confirmed.

Date: The Sinking of the Moskva
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: The flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet was damaged by a fire or a Ukrainian missile.

Date: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
Title: At first glance, Sergey Gushchin, 50, is perhaps not a man one would assume to be the Russian consul general at the world’s northernmost diplomatic mission: ponytail, bluejeans, bass player in a punk band.
Text: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.

Date: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
Title: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Date: Gina McCarthy, Top Climate Adviser, Is Said to Be Planning Departure
Title: Gina McCarthy, the White House climate adviser, has told confidants that she has been frustrated by the slow pace of climate progress and intends to step down in the coming months, according to several people to whom she has spoken.
Text: Ms. McCarthy was tapped by President Biden to lead an ambitious domestic climate agenda. Associates say she is frustrated by the slow pace of progress.

Date: C.I.A. Director Airs Concern That Putin Might Turn to Nuclear Weapons
Title: The director of the C.I.A. said on Thursday that “potential desperation” to extract the semblance of a victory in Ukraine could tempt President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to order the use of a tactical or low-yield nuclear weapon, publicly discussing for the first time a concern that has coursed through the White House during seven weeks of conflict.
Text: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, cautioned that he had seen no “practical evidence” that would suggest such a move was imminent.

Date: The Cat’s Approval Was a Good Start
Title: Even after being together for nearly two decades, Stuart Rembaum still struggled to find the words when it came to discussing a possible wedding to Jim Post.
Text: but not before Mr. Rembaum’s cat “sanctioned the relationship” by allowing Mr. Post to pet her.

Date: In a Week, Moving a Wedding from Ukraine to New York
Title: On a Wednesday evening in late February, Meny Stambler and Rikel Deutch talked to each other on the phone for the last time before their wedding.
Text: In their last phone call before they married, Meny Stambler, who is Ukrainian, and Rikel Deutch, who is Russian, expected to wed in Ukraine. Hours after they hung up, Russian troops had invaded.

Date: War Brings New Iron Curtain Down on Russia’s Storied Ballet Stages
Title: Just days after the invasion of Ukraine, Olga Smirnova, one of Russia’s most important ballerinas, posted an emotional statement on Telegram, the messaging app. “I am against war with all the fibers of my soul,” she wrote.
Text: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.

Date: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
Title: On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.
Text: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.

Date: Fuel Prices Send Airfares Higher, but Travelers Seem Ready to Pay
Title: A stunning rise in the cost of jet fuel has sent airfares soaring, and industry experts say they are likely to go higher. For now, though, travel-starved consumers seem more than willing to pay up.
Text: Supplies are not keeping up with demand, and costs may go higher, experts say.

Date: Some U.F.C. Fighters Have Ties to a Chechen Leader Loyal to Putin
Title: Khamzat Chimaev’s victory last weekend in a bruising fight served as a declaration in mixed martial arts: Chimaev, an undefeated welterweight, is quickly becoming the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s next superstar.
Text: Ramzan Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, is facing U.S. sanctions and accused of brutal abuses. Yet some fighters and others who work with the U.F.C. have kept ties with him.

Date: Faced With a Changed Europe, China Sticks to an Old Script
Title: When European leaders recently pressed China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, to distance himself from Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, he doggedly stuck to prepared remarks for the video summit, shutting down any opening for their demands.
Text: Europe was viewed as lacking the power and the will to contest China’s rise. But now, a harder line toward Russia has implications for Beijing.

Date: The (Really) Big Boats Have Arrived
Title: It has taken a few years, delayed by the pandemic, but formal Maxi yacht racing is coming to the Caribbean, considerably increasing the competitive opportunities sailors have to race their sleek monohull behemoths that can reach 100 feet long.
Text: Those enormous, pricey Maxi yachts have joined the Caribbean racing season and will be at Les Voiles de St. Barth.

Date: Growing Religious Fervor on the Right and the Illusions Shattered by Putin’s War: The Week in Narrated Articles
Title: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
Text: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

Date: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
Title: Shortly before midnight on a spring night last year, Samia Suluhu Hassan, then Tanzania’s first female vice president, appeared on television to announce to a shocked nation that the president was dead.
Text: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.

Date: Russia’s loss of its Black Sea flagship would make capturing Odesa harder, analysts say.
Title: The loss of the Russian Navy’s Black Sea Fleet flagship will make it more difficult to gain full control over Ukraine’s southern coast and ultimately move on the port city of Odesa, military analysts say, although it is unlikely to derail Moscow’s war campaign entirely.

Date: Quiz Time on the Campaign Trail
Title: During the first week of the federal election campaign, politicians have been asked about: the price of bread, milk and petrol; the JobSeeker rate; the wage price index; the cash rate; the unemployment rate, and more.
Text: Several “gotcha” questions for candidates, including one that Anthony Albanese got wrong, raise deeper questions about the quality of the nation’s political discourse.

Date: How Russian disinformation spreads beyond its borders.
Title: not Russia — are to blame for Russia’s attack.
Text: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.

Date: U.S. Offers Protection to People Who Fled War in Cameroon
Title: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would offer temporary protected status to nationals of Cameroon, shielding them from deportation and enabling them to obtain work permits, amid escalating armed conflict that has spawned a humanitarian crisis in the African country.
Text: Temporary protected status will allow an estimated 40,000 Cameroonians to legally live and work in the United States.

Date: What Britain’s Deal With Rwanda Means for the U.K. Asylum System
Title: The British government has announced a plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, a move that prompted an immediate backlash from opposition politicians, international legal experts and human rights defenders.
Text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?

Date: You Decide Which Games Matter
Title: Only a little more than a year ago, the Europa Conference League was still just an idea. It did not, in truth, even seem like an especially good idea. Explaining where such a league would fit into the game’s pecking order, what its purpose would be, hardly had the making of a compelling elevator pitch.
Text: The F.A. Cup and the Conference League have meaning not because of tradition or design, but when the players, and particularly the fans, decide they are important.

Date: Brazil’s climate politics are shifting. That matters for the whole planet.
Title: In Brazil, beef isn’t just food. It’s political. It’s a symbol of dignity and equality, and the price of beef is a kind of barometer of well-being in the country.
Text: The Amazon is emerging as a central issue in this year’s presidential campaign. Leaders have taken note.

Date: Russia’s Black Sea flagship was hit by 2 Ukrainian missiles, a U.S. official says.
Title: Two Ukrainian Neptune missiles hit Russia’s flagship Moskva in the Black Sea, a senior Defense official said on Friday, providing the first American confirmation that the sinking of the Russian cruiser was the result of a Ukrainian strike.
Text: Moscow claimed the sinking was an accident, but U.S. intelligence reports say the cruiser went down after Ukraine struck it with Neptune missiles.

Date: Why Ukraine War Crimes Trials Could Take Many Years
Title: The brutalities of Russia’s war in Ukraine have stoked enormous demand among Ukrainians and much of the Western world for investigations, indictments, arrests and trials for the invaders and their commanders, notably President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Some leaders, including President Biden, have even accused them of genocide.
Text: Long after the fighting ends, any prosecutions and trials arising from it could be barely beginning. Here is a look at the complexities of bringing aggressors to justice.

Date: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
Title: on ice skates. She agrees, but not because she is patriotic: Caroline has been told that a camp on the other side of the vast frozen expanse holds her daughter, who was abducted years earlier.
Text: This month’s picks take viewers through time loops, economic collapse and dystopian rage, with Noomi Rapace along for the journey.

Date: How Russian Media Uses Fox News to Make Its Case
Title: As Western leaders introduced sanctions against Russia for the invasion of Ukraine, Tucker Carlson, the Fox News host, said seizing personal property from Russian oligarchs went too far.
Text: The conservative network has appeared hundreds of times in Russian media.

Date: ‘Thank You for Not Killing Us’
Title: The first sign of trouble was when a squad of Chechen soldiers burst through the gate.
Text: An ordeal at a mental health facility in Ukraine illuminated the horrors of the Russian occupation in the areas around Kyiv.

Date: Biden Plans to Open More Public Land to Drilling
Title: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would resume selling leases for new oil and gas drilling on public lands, but would also raise the federal royalties that companies must pay to drill, the first increase in those fees in more than a century.
Text: The president is under pressure to bring down gas prices, but any new drilling would be years away. The fees that companies pay would rise sharply.

Date: The Horrors of Russian Occupation
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Disturbing stories are emerging of the terror inflicted on Ukrainian civilians.

Date: Your Friday Evening Briefing
Title: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Date: The War in Ukraine Is Upending Biden’s Agenda at Home
Title: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has scrambled the global foreign policy landscape. But it has also upended President Biden’s domestic agenda back home, diverting the attention of the White House and contributing to rising prices that have become a top concern of Americans just months before congressional elections.
Text: President Biden’s domestic ambitions have gotten smaller as the war diverts the attention of the White House and contributes to rising prices.

Date: Girding for New Battle, Russia Warns U.S. on Advanced Weapons for Ukraine
Title: Stung by war losses and massing troops for a new battle in eastern Ukraine, Russia has warned the Biden administration to stop supplying advanced weapons to Ukrainian forces or face “unpredictable consequences,” American officials said Friday.
Text: The warnings were regarded as a sign that American military assistance to Ukraine was compounding problems for the Russians in their two-month-old invasion.

Date: Oh, Brother: The Not-Quite-Tell-All Books by Presidential Sisters
Title: In her 1921 biography about her brother Theodore Roosevelt, Corrine Roosevelt Robinson saw no harm in sharing “almost confidential personal recollections” about the late president. “There is no sacrilege in sharing such memories, with the people who have loved him, and whom he loved so well,” she wrote.
Text: Valerie Biden Owens is one of a handful of presidential sisters who have taken the opportunity to dish on their brothers.

Date: Prized Russian Ship Was Hit by Missiles, U.S. Officials Say
Title: The Moskva was the pride of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, a symbol of the country’s dominance of the region and a powerful war machine that had been used to launch precision cruise missiles deep inside Ukraine.
Text: The sinking of the Moskva was a major blow to the Russian fleet and the most significant combat loss for any navy in decades.

Date: Travel’s ‘Great Comeback’ Has a Price: Chaos
Title: Arriving at London’s Gatwick Airport for his easyJet flight to Malaga, Spain, with his wife and 12-year-old daughter on April 4, Alasdair Crawley said it was like walking into the mayhem of the aftermath of a soccer game. The 49-year-old plumber from East London described long unruly lines of angry passengers trying to determine the status of their flights and families sprawled out across the floor eating, drinking and sleeping to get through long delays.
Text: In recent weeks, travelers on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean have endured long lines at airports, flight delays or cancellations, and plenty of frustration. Is this the new normal?

Date: He Envisioned a Nightmarish, Dystopian Russia. Now He Fears Living in One.
Title: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Text: With eight forthcoming translations of his books, Vladimir Sorokin is gaining recognition in the West just as, he says, Russian writers need to fight back in a semantic war on truth.

Date: A Case for Cautious Optimism, Now That the Markets Are So Glum
Title: The headlines about inflation have, once again, been awful. Consumer prices are rising more rapidly than at any time since 1981, and producer prices are soaring as well.
Text: Stocks, bonds and commodities are already pricing in inflation, the pandemic and war.

Date: Putin’s Ukraine Gamble Pivots to a Very Different Battlefield
Title: There are fields instead of city streets, farmsteads instead of apartment buildings. Open highways stretch to the horizon.
Text: After Russian forces were mauled in cities and towns in northern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is shifting the focus of his invasion to the flatlands of Donbas, in the east.

Date: Where Russians Turn for Uncensored News on Ukraine
Title: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Russian journalist Farida Rustamova used the Telegram chat app for one purpose: messaging friends.
Text: Telegram is the platform of choice for Russians seeking to escape Moscow’s propaganda web. But can it last?

Date: War in Ukraine Has Left Eastern Europe Sleepless
Title: For the past seven weeks, Dr. Simona Neliubsiene has struggled to focus on her patients’ charts, distracted by images of bombed cities flashing in her head.
Text: Mental health professionals across the region say they have seen an increase in patients with intense anxiety. Some are asking for more sleeping pills, and many are making escape plans.

Date: A Nazi Soldier Stole a Watch in 1942. It Turned Up 80 Years Later.
Title: After nearly 80 years, a watch that was taken by a Nazi soldier during World War II, lost in a cornfield and later hidden in a clock on a farm in Belgium has been returned to the grandchildren of its maker.
Text: The watch, made as a gift in 1910, has been returned to the maker’s family in the Netherlands. It still works.

Date: The Moskva’s sinking inspires one of Ukraine’s most popular rockers.
Title: The sinking of the Russian warship Moskva is being celebrated by Ukrainians as an iconic victory, including in a new song by one of the country’s most popular rock musicians.
Text: Vadym Krasnooky, whose band Mad Heads had stopped performing when the war began, said his new song is meant to ‘channel all this hate.’

Date: A Russian Default Is Looming. A Bitter Fight Is Likely to Follow.
Title: Russia is ambling toward a major default on its foreign debt, a grim milestone that it has not seen since the Bolshevik Revolution more than a century ago and one that raises the prospect of years of legal wrangling and a global hunt by bondholders for Russian assets.
Text: The ultimate arbiter of a sovereign default is an open question but markets may have the final word.

Date: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
Title: Russia pounded military targets throughout Ukraine on Saturday, in apparent retaliation for the sinking of an important naval ship and in preparation for an offensive in the Donbas region of the country’s east.
Text: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.

Date: Fighting for Her Life, Far From Ukraine
Title: When Russia invaded Ukraine, Marija Pyzhyk was still worried mainly about her 5-year-old daughter, Khrystyna, who was being treated for a brain tumor. The family lived in Lviv, the western city near Poland, far from the rockets raining down in the east.
Text: A 5-year-old Ukrainian girl with a brain tumor was one of several children brought for treatment in the United States after their country was invaded by Russia.

Date: The World’s Broken Promise of Asylum
Title: For more than 70 years, the world has enshrined, in national laws and global agreements, a promise that was presented as vitally important: Anyone who cannot live safely in their home country may seek refuge in another.
Text: Britain’s new plan to send thousands of asylum seekers to Rwanda exposes the fragile nature of the global refugee compact, which has always fallen prey to domestic politics.

Date: ‘They Are Gone, Vanished’: Missing Persons Haunt Ukrainian Village
Title: The cows wouldn’t stop screaming.
Text: In a Russian-occupied village, five men went off to feed cattle. Their relatives and neighbors are wondering what happened to them.

Date: The Week in Business: Housing Market Gets Squeezed
Title: Mortgage rates rose to 5 percent for the first time in more than a decade, the kind of increase that in the past spelled trouble for the housing market. But in the current climate, the impact of the higher rates is uncertain. During the pandemic, many people, with extra savings in their pockets and in search of more space, bid up house prices. That, combined with supply chain problems that slowed construction of new homes, stoked competition and made new houses hard to come by. The inventory of homes for sale remains extremely low, and there are still more interested buyers than there are houses. But if the market doesn’t feel the sting, prospective home buyers certainly will, especially those who are already struggling with the rising costs of food, gas, cars and other everyday necessities.
Text: Elon Musk wants to take over Twitter. Prices are still rising at a rapid pace, but even with higher ticket prices, airlines are seeing demand rebound.

Date: Pope Francis calls for peace in Ukraine and the world on what he described as an ‘Easter of war.’
Title: Ukraine hung heavily on Pope Francis’ heart on Sunday as he delivered the annual “Urbi et Orbi” (“To the City and the World”) message in St. Peter’s Square, in which he called for peace on what he described this year as an “Easter of war.”
Text: Instead of learning from the heavy toll taken by the pandemic, and emerging with strengthened solidarity, rivalry had prevailed, the pope said.

Date: Worshipers filled pews in Lviv on Easter Sunday.
Title: Ukrainians packed churches on Sunday for Easter commemorations that combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.
Text: Commemorations in Ukraine’s small Roman Catholic community combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.

Date: Questions deepen in Russia, days after the sinking of a warship.
Title: A video released by Russia’s Ministry of Defense purporting to show dozens of uniformed crew members from the missile cruiser Moskva standing in formation, apparently days after the ship sank, did not answer lingering questions about the fate of the vessel and its more than 500 personnel.
Text: A talk-show host, who usually reflects the Kremlin’s line, questioned how the ship was lost.

Date: Pope Speaks of Ukraine’s Suffering on ‘an Easter of War’
Title: On what he described this year as an “Easter of war,” Pope Francis spoke to tens of thousands of faithful in St. Peter’s Square about the “fear and anguish” evoked by the conflict in Ukraine, adding that he hoped news of suffering in Europe would also make people more mindful of similar situations elsewhere.
Text: In his blessing to pilgrims, Pope Francis quoted a manifesto against nuclear weapons and said conflict in Europe should bring increased attention to violence around the world.

Date: Atrocities in Ukraine War Have Deep Roots in Russian Military
Title: In a photograph from the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, Ukraine, a woman stands in the yard of a house, her hand covering her mouth in horror, the bodies of three dead civilians scattered before her. When Aset Chad saw that picture, she started shaking and hurtled 22 years back in time.
Text: Like the shelling of cities, the seemingly pointless, close-up killing of individuals recalls wars in Chechnya. Do they reflect intent, or only indifference, propaganda and a military culture of violence?

Date: A Visiting Team Like No Other
Title: The Ukrainian comeback attempt had come up just short, and Dayana Yastremska and her four teammates were preparing to pose for their final formal photograph at this Billie Jean King Cup qualifier.
Text: A supportive tennis crowd in Asheville, N.C., watched the Ukrainians nearly pull off an upset of the United States in a Billie Jean King Cup qualifier.

Date: Jim Farley Tries to Reinvent Ford and Catch Up to Elon Musk and Tesla
Title: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Jim Farley, the chief executive of Ford Motor, took a spin in what could become one of the most important vehicles in the company’s 118-year history: an electric F-150 pickup truck.
Text: Ford’s chief executive is about to introduce an electric F-150 pickup truck that could determine whether the automaker can survive and thrive in an industry dominated by Tesla.

Date: Sadness and Loss Are Everywhere. Books Can Help.
Title: I was 10 when “Brian’s Song” aired in 1971 as an ABC Movie of the Week. It is the story of the abiding friendship that grew as Brian Piccolo, who was white, and Gale Sayers, who was Black, competed for playing time as N.F.L. rookies with the Chicago Bears. It’s also the story of Piccolo’s death of cancer at 26. I was a girl in Birmingham, Ala., then “the most segregated city in America,” when “Brian’s Song” reminded this country that race was not an insurmountable barrier to love.
Text: The saddest stories can show us how full of grace the fallen world can be.

Date: The Next Hurdle in Europe’s Energy Transition: Being More Enticing Than NFTs
Title: When Jakob Bitner was 7, he left Russia for Germany with his parents and sister. Twenty-eight years later, he is set on solving a vexing green-energy problem that could help Germany end its dependence on imported energy from Russia, or anywhere.
Text: Financing the next generation of green energy technologies means larger investments and getting venture capitalists to turn their attention away from “fast money.”

Date: French Candidates’ Economic Programs Hold Key to the Election
Title: As President Emmanuel Macron wove through crowds during a campaign stop in northern France last week, an elderly voter got in his face to protest one of his most unpopular economic proposals: raising the retirement age to 65 from 62 to fund France’s national pension system.
Text: Promising tax cuts, higher wages and changes in the retirement age, President Macron and Marine Le Pen vie for undecided voters.

Date: They’re Some of Hollywood’s Top Publicists. Just Don’t Ask Them Why.
Title: “I can’t decide what is OK and what’s not OK, you know what I mean?” Amanda Silverman said over the phone on March 1, six days into Russia’s war on Ukraine. Discussing geopolitics was not the intended purpose of the call; Ms. Silverman’s life as a celebrity publicist was. As Vladimir Putin shook the world order, she had clients to manage.
Text: Meet the women of the Lede Company.

Date: Rushing Against War, and Time, Ukraine Makes It to the Biennale
Title: The 78 bronze funnels were ready, the pump tested and the backdrop was almost done. So when it looked as if war was most likely coming to Ukraine, Maria Lanko, one of the curators of the Ukrainian pavilion at the Venice Biennale, was determined to get the artist Pavlo Makov’s fountain sculpture safely out of the country.
Text: Russia’s invasion complicated well-laid plans. But, despite the odds, Ukraine will present work at the international art showcase in Venice.

Date: Russian attack on Lviv shakes sense of security in a relatively safe city.
Title: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.

Date: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
Title: It was in early March when the spent warhead of a cluster munition rocket landed next to Yurii Doroshenko’s home in eastern Ukraine, having dispensed its lethal bomblets over his village.
Text: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.

Date: Five Big Questions for Elon Musk and Twitter
Title: Over the weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who, you might have heard, wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.
Text: Will he go hostile, what is Twitter really worth and more.

Date: A Russian strike hits Lviv, a city relatively untouched by violence.
Title: Russian missiles struck Lviv on Monday, killing at least seven people in the first reported deaths of the war in the western city, where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have fled to escape the fierce fighting in other parts of Ukraine.
Text: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.

Date: The World Bank slashes its forecast for global economic growth.
Title: The World Bank is slashing its forecast for global economic growth this year, citing the war in Ukraine, inflation and the lingering effects of the pandemic.
Text: The bank now expects the global economy to grow at a rate of 3.2 percent in 2022, down from its previous estimate of 4.1 percent.

Date: Bleak assessments of the Russian economy clash with Putin’s rosy claims.
Title: Russia’s central bank chief warned on Monday that the consequences of Western sanctions were only beginning to be felt, and Moscow’s mayor said that 200,000 jobs were at risk in the Russian capital alone, stark acknowledgments that undermined President Vladimir V. Putin’s contention that sanctions had failed to destabilize the Russian economy.
Text: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.

Date: Bank of America is confident in the economy even as its profits declined.
Title: Bank of America joined its peers in reporting lower profits for the first three months of the year but is keeping its optimistic economic outlook even as other lending giants have turned more cautious.
Text: The bank reported lower quarterly profits, but it expects to earn significantly more money later this year from rising interest rates.

Date: A second global Covid-19 summit led by the White House is set for May.
Title: The White House announced on Monday that it would co-host the second global Covid-19 summit next month, a gathering intended to build momentum for vaccine donations and for ending what the White House called the “acute phase” of the pandemic.
Text: Efforts to subsidize more global vaccinations have stalled in Congress, and new coronavirus cases are on the rise in the U.S.

Date: Citing Ukraine War, an American Resigns From Russia’s Mariinsky
Title: The American conductor Gavriel Heine has been a fixture at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, for 15 years. He has led hundreds of performances of classics like “Swan Lake” and “The Rite of Spring.” And he has done so as a protégé of the company’s leader: Valery Gergiev.
Text: “There’s no way I could ever be in denial of what is happening,” said the conductor Gavriel Heine, a fixture at the prestigious Russian theater.

Date: Ukraine War Divides Orthodox Faithful
Title: IT specialists, migrant factory laborers, nurses and cleaners — decided to repudiate the full-throated support for the war in Ukraine from Patriarch Kirill of Moscow.
Text: Around the world, national churches, parishes and even families are reassessing relations with Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, who has encouraged Russia’s aggression.

Date: Thousands of civilians are holed up with Ukrainian troops in Mariupol, officials say.
Title: Intense fighting continued around a large steel factory in the southern city of Mariupol, in what appeared to be one of the last redoubts of Ukrainian forces in the besieged city, an adviser to the mayor said on Monday.
Text: Some 2,000 civilians who were driven from their homes have sheltered in a network of tunnels beneath the plant, an aide to the city’s mayor said.

Date: They Fled Afghanistan for America. Now They Feed the Newest Arrivals.
Title: Hamidullah Noori was 8 years old when his father, uncle and cousin were killed by Taliban militants in Kabul, Afghanistan. As the eldest son, he soon went to work to support his family, selling boiled potatoes and balloons from a pushcart. Violence and flight have shaped his life ever since.
Text: In Virginia, Maryland and Washington, D.C., established Afghan restaurateurs are reaching out to help refugees fleeing the return of the Taliban.

Date: Prominent prisoners held by both sides appeal for an exchange.
Title: High-profile prisoners held by both Russia and Ukraine, including two British fighters believed captured in Mariupol, appealed on Monday to be exchanged.
Text: Two British fighters held by Russian asked to be traded for Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian ally of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.

Date: The Battle for the Donbas
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun, Ukraine says.

Date: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
Title: Ukraine said Monday that Russian forces had launched a ground assault along a nearly 300-mile front in the east after hitting the country with one of the most intense missile barrages in weeks, including the first lethal strike on Lviv, the western city that has been a refuge for tens of thousands of fleeing civilians.
Text: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.

Date: Your Monday Evening Briefing
Title: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Date: The U.N.’s humanitarian chief said he tested positive for the coronavirus after attending in-person meetings.
Title: Martin Griffiths, the top humanitarian chief at the United Nations, said he tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday as he was visiting the U.N. headquarters in New York from a recent trip to Afghanistan, Russia and Ukraine.
Text: One meeting had included the U.N.’s secretary general, but everyone in the room was wearing masks, a spokesman said.

Date: This Venice Biennale Has a New Star: Women
Title: The Venice Biennale, the world’s longest-running major survey of contemporary art, will reconvene this weekend after a yearlong postponement because of the pandemic. Barring another coronavirus surge, the 59th edition of the world’s oldest international exhibition, which opens to the public on Saturday and runs through Nov. 27, should attract hundreds of thousands of visitors.
Text: For the first time, a majority of the artists at the 59th edition of the longest-running survey of contemporary art will be female.

Date: The Cost of Dissidence in Russia
Title: Nearly two months into the war in Ukraine, many Russians have gone from shock and denial to support for their troops and anger at the West.
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin’s us-versus-them framing of the war has set the country up for a new and dark phase domestically.

Date: Netflix loses subscribers for first time in 10 years.
Title: 200,000 overall in the first three months of the year — the result of shifting economic forces, increasingly fierce competition from other streaming platforms and the conflict in Ukraine. The Tuesday announcement, plus the company’s warning that it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter, sent the stock down 35 percent on Wednesday.
Text: The company, which had a net loss of 200,000 subscribers in its first quarter, has been facing down a lack of must-see content on its platform as competitors continue to expand.

Date: The Next Big Thing in Streaming
Title: Later today, Netflix will report its latest quarterly earnings. Analysts do not have high expectations. The streaming service’s profits are expected to drop by more than 20 percent.
Text: As subscriber growth slows, Netflix and others show less resistance to introducing ads.

Date: Russia’s Thrust in Eastern Ukraine Combines Firepower and New Caution
Title: Russia’s initial invasion of Ukraine in February relied on a rapid advance of tanks and helicopter assaults deep into the country — two strategies that ultimately failed and cost Moscow a significant number of casualties.
Text: The military campaign that Moscow said it had now begun appears much more methodical than those it pursued in the war’s first days

Date: Global Economic Forecasts Drop as Russia’s War in Ukraine Takes Toll
Title: The world economy has entered a period of intense uncertainty as a capricious pandemic and the fallout from Russia’s war in Ukraine combine to fuel rapid inflation and weigh on an already fragile global recovery.
Text: The International Monetary Fund’s new World Economic Outlook expects growth to slow to 3.6 percent this year. The group is one of many to slash their forecasts recently.

Date: Ukraine’s War Efforts Gain an Unlikely Source of Funding: Memes
Title: Christian Borys was at home in Toronto in February trying to find a way to help Ukrainians threatened by war when he decided to print some stickers from an internet meme: the Virgin Mary hoisting an antitank missile.
Text: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.

Date: For Airlines, the Mask Mandate Couldn’t End Soon Enough
Title: For two years, covered faces in airports and on airplanes were a persistent reminder of the hold that the coronavirus had on air travel. The end of the mask mandate on planes and other forms of transportation this week marked the latest advance in the airline industry’s effort to return to normal.
Text: It created tensions between flight attendants and noncompliant passengers, but some travelers are worried about what comes next.

Date: Drawn and Caricatured: French Cartoonists on the Campaign Trail
Title: There is little time left until the French choose their next president on Sunday, and image is important. As media teams flutter around the two remaining candidates, President Emmanuel Macron and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen, the nation’s political cartoonists are out in force, ready to accentuate even the smallest slip.
Text: Cartoonists play a high-profile role in France’s political discourse, and they have been busy drawing the presidential candidates as the race approaches its end.

Date: China doubles down on coal
Title: What happens in China doesn’t stay in China. Certainly not when it comes to global warming.
Text: Choices being made about energy in the country right now will have profound implications for the climate crisis.

Date: Ukrainian Children and Caregivers Are Being Separated at U.S. Border
Title: After Iryna Merezhko persuaded her sister in Ukraine that her young nephew should join her in Los Angeles to wait out the war, she traveled halfway around the globe to pick him up. “I told him it would be a California vacation,” she recalled. “We would go to Disneyland, Universal Studios, the beach.”
Text: Under a policy designed to protect young refugees from trafficking, Ukrainian children are being temporarily removed from caretakers who are not their parents.

Date: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’
Title: Under incessant fire from the air and with Russian troops closing in, a group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the besieged city of Mariupol issued a message of despair on Tuesday evening, expressing hope that their own forces would come to their rescue and demanding that the world do something to stop the Kremlin’s vicious war.
Text: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.

Date: Johnson Is All Apologies Before Parliament After ‘Partygate’ Fine
Title: Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced Parliament on Tuesday as an awkward pioneer in British politics: a confirmed lawbreaker who misled fellow lawmakers but remains ensconced in the nation’s highest elected office.
Text: Though opposition politicians called him out, only one member of his own Conservative party called on him to resign.

Date: Democratic Dollars Flow Once Again to Likely Lost Causes
Title: Gary Chambers Jr. burst onto the national scene in 2020 with a viral video of him castigating the racism of the East Baton Rouge school district. Now, he has captured the hearts and wallets of young liberals with a video for his improbable Senate campaign that shows him smoking a large joint and calling for the legalization of marijuana.
Text: New fund-raising figures show emerging Democratic stars like Marcus Flowers in Georgia and Gary Chambers Jr. in Louisiana, with no clear path to victory.

Date: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
Title: The race is on.
Text: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.

Date: Russia’s Strategy in the East
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Russia is taking a more methodical approach in its Donbas campaign.

Date: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
Title: Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

Date: More Cautious, Russia Embarks on New Phase of Ukraine War
Title: Russia plunged into a new chapter of the Ukraine war on Tuesday, intent on capturing the eastern part of the country and crushing Ukrainian defenses without the same blunders that badly damaged Russian forces in the conflict’s initial weeks.
Text: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.

Date: Russia rejects calls for a cease-fire to enable evacuations, saying Ukraine only wants time to arm.
Title: Russia rejected calls for a cease-fire to allow for civilian evacuations in Ukraine on Tuesday, saying that requests to pause the fighting were not sincere and would only provide time to arm Ukrainian fighters.
Text: Civilians, including children, remain trapped in the eastern Ukraine region of Donbas and in the devastated port city of Mariupol.

Date: Tours Argue Wimbledon Sets ‘Damaging Precedent’ in Barring Russian and Belarusian Players
Title: Professional tennis, which had been unusually united of late, is back in disaccord after Wimbledon’s bold and difficult decision to bar Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tournament was met with strong disapproval by the men’s and women’s tours.
Text: The men’s and women’s tours disagreed with the major tournament’s move to exclude individual athletes from those countries from competition in the aftermath of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Date: How The Times Has Mapped the War in Ukraine
Title: and nearly every graphics journalist at the organization, from New York to Seoul to London, has helped with the mapping effort.
Text: Graphics journalists use annotated maps to show readers the current state of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Date: Feeling the Squeeze? How to Be a Thrifty Traveler as Prices Soar
Title: compounded by pent-up demand — peaks.
Text: Inflation is here and it’s wreaking havoc on travel budgets. Our Frugal Traveler columnist on how to strategize in a world of rising prices.

Date: In the fog of dementia, one grandmother learns again and again that her country is at war.
Title: Every morning, Olga Boichak’s grandmother wakes up at her home in western Ukraine, turns on the television and discovers anew that her country is at war.
Text: Millions of Ukrainians have been displaced since the war started. Many elderly or disabled people have been unable or unwilling to leave their homes.

Date: A Problem for Macron in France’s Election: ‘The Hatred He Arouses’
Title: Follow our live updates of the French runoff election between Macron and Le Pen.
Text: Given the choice between a president they suspect of despising ordinary people and a far-right candidate they detest, many French voters may stay home.

Date: The End of Mask Mandates
Title: Major U.S. airlines have lifted mask mandates after a federal judge ruled that face coverings would no longer be required on airplanes, trains and other public transportation.
Text: As major airlines and some public transit operators drop requirements to wear face coverings, further conflicts may be on the horizon.

Date: Netflix shares plunge 35 percent after announcing subscriber losses.
Title: Netflix shares tumbled 35 percent Wednesday after the company announced a loss of 200,000 subscribers in the first quarter of the year.
Text: The streaming company said 200,000 subscribers left its platform in the first quarter.

Date: She’s the Peggy Guggenheim of SoHo
Title: Think of her as Peggy Guggenheim in reverse. Laura Mattioli Rossi: an Italian, not an American, living in New York, not Venice, near Canal Street, not the Grand Canal. She established and runs a private foundation in New York, the Center for Italian Modern Art (CIMA), which recalls the private, one-woman Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice.
Text: Steward of a collection of 20th century art, Laura Mattioli made a future for the Futurists at the Center for Italian Modern Art in Manhattan.

Date: Why ‘Border Control’ Politics Is More About Control Than Borders
Title: Sometimes I choose a newsletter topic because it’s in the headlines. Sometimes it’s to point out a phenomenon that is shaping politics around the world, in ways that often go unnoticed, and to explain how to recognize its fingerprints on news events that recur reliably month after month.
Text: A quirk of political psychology helps explain the British government’s plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.

Date: Russia says it has successfully tested a new intercontinental missile that can evade defenses.
Title: Russia announced on Wednesday it had successfully launched a new missile that it said could deploy nuclear warheads at hypersonic speeds anywhere in the world and outwit defenses, a move that President Vladimir V. Putin said was aimed at showing Russia’s adversaries that they needed to “think twice” before threatening his country.
Text: Though officials said the missile is not yet ready to deploy, President Vladimir V. Putin said the launch of the Sarmat missile “will force all who are trying to threaten our country in the heat of frenzied, aggressive rhetoric to think twice.”

Date: Why Everyone Wants to Buy Twitter
Title: Elon Musk is the latest rich guy to have fallen for the trap of Twitter.
Text: Elon Musk is the latest person who thinks he can fulfill Twitter’s untapped potential.

Date: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen walked out of a G20 meeting as Russia’s finance minister spoke.
Title: Several finance ministers and central bankers including Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen and Ukraine’s finance minister, Serhiy Marchenko, abruptly left a Group of 20 meeting in protest on Wednesday when Russia’s finance minister, Anton Siluanov, started to speak, according to a person familiar with the meeting.
Text: Several central bank governors and finance ministers protested Russia’s participation at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.

Date: Calls to Give Heavy Weapons to Ukraine Divide Germany’s Government
Title: Fierce debate over sending heavy weapons to Ukraine has struck a fault line through Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government, raising questions about his leadership and dampening expectations of his ability to help steer Europe through the continent’s most dramatic security crisis since World War II.
Text: Weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a paradigm shift in military strategy, his government is struggling to balance domestic politics, how to help Ukraine and anxiety over provoking Russia.

Date: A Ukrainian Town Goes Underground as Russia Assaults the East
Title: Spartak Kyurdzhiev was bragging to friends on Wednesday that he never hides from bombings anymore when a volley of rocket fire landed with such intensity nearby that he dashed into the school he was standing in front of.
Text: As Ukrainian forces dig into trenches and residents flee into basements, Russia’s artillery attacks have intensified. “They can’t get through the front lines and so they’re starting simply to destroy the city,” a Ukrainian official said.

Date: The Treasury Department takes action to crack down on Russian sanctions evasion.
Title: The Treasury Department on Wednesday moved to crack down on Russia’s efforts to evade sanctions by imposing a new set of measures targeting a Russian bank, a cryptocurrency mining company and a network of individuals who are accused of facilitating illicit transactions.
Text: New sanctions target a Russian bank and cryptocurrency mining company.

Date: A German software giant is unplugging its Russia business.
Title: In the days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the German software giant SAP halted all its sales in Russia. But it provoked the ire of Ukrainian leaders by continuing to offer updates and cloud computing access to Russian customers not targeted by Western sanctions.
Text: As SAP takes steps to wind down its cloud services in Russia, Continental said it was required to “temporarily” restart a Russian tire factory.

Date: He Was a Penniless Donor to the Far Right. He Was Also a Russian Spy.
Title: He lived with his sick mother and never had a regular job. He had no obvious source of income and, according to his uncle, even signed up for welfare benefits as a caregiver deserving of state support.
Text: An investigation in Slovakia has exposed how Russian clandestine operations are trying to sow discord in Europe and create sympathy for Moscow over Ukraine.

Date: On the Front Line in the East
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Ukrainians in the Donbas are facing new perils from war.

Date: Netflix’s Stumble Could Be a Warning Sign for Streaming Industry
Title: Many entertainment executives, tired of playing catch-up to a Silicon Valley interloper, have been waiting for the comeuppance of Netflix. But this may not have been the way they hoped it would happen.
Text: The company faces a number of challenges, but its problems may be an indication that its competitors are racing toward an unstable future.

Date: Aid groups fight to deliver lifesaving supplies despite losing lives to Russian shelling.
Title: On a bracingly cold day in March, four people set out from Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, to deliver lifesaving medicines, heating devices and food to the besieged residents of Chernihiv, in the northeast.
Text: Only one member of an aid convoy to Chernihiv, Ukraine, survived a shelling attack in March. But the convoy’s organizers have persisted through the dangers of the war.

Title: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Date: Russia’s Missile Test Fuels U.S. Fears of an Isolated Putin
Title: President Vladimir V. Putin’s calculated move on Wednesday to test-launch a new intercontinental ballistic missile, declaring it a warning to those in the West who “try to threaten our country,” fed into a growing concern inside the Biden administration: that Russia is now so isolated from the rest of the world that Mr. Putin sees little downside to provocative actions.
Text: American and foreign leaders have been weighing whether their success in making Russia a diplomatic pariah could push President Vladimir V. Putin to strike in new ways.

Date: Warning Ukraine’s Friends to ‘Think Twice,’ Putin Tests Advanced Missile
Title: With a pointed warning to Ukraine’s Western allies, Russia test-launched a new intercontinental missile on Wednesday, even as it unleashed a hail of bombs, artillery and missiles inside Ukraine in a drive to weaken Ukrainian defenses for a major ground offensive in the east.
Text: Vladimir Putin said Russia’s test-firing of its new I.C.B.M. sends a message, as his forces prepare for a broad offensive in eastern Ukraine.

Date: See Mariupol’s Azovstal steel-mill fortress in peacetime, and then after nearly two months of war.
Title: In late January, while in Mariupol reporting on how Ukrainian forces were bracing for a Russian invasion, a New York Times video team captured drone footage over the Azovstal Iron and Steel works plant, an engine of industry for the southern port city.
Text: Before-and-after images show the scale of destruction that the Ukrainian port city has suffered after nearly two months of near constant bombardment by Russian artillery, mortars and airstrikes.

Date: Macron and Le Pen Trade Punches in Pivotal Debate on France’s Future
Title: Follow our live updates of the French runoff election between Macron and Le Pen.
Text: He attacked the far-right leader as a Putin stooge. She hit back at him as the president of division and contempt.

Date: The Shock of Chopping Up a Chanel Bag
Title: Marina Ermoshkina, a Russian television host, typically fills her Instagram with glamorous selfies: couture clad on red carpets; bikini clad on Riviera beaches; smiling aboard yachts. But last week she decided to express her anger over Chanel’s new restrictions on sales to Russian nationals, by slicing up her pearl-gray leather shoulder bag worth about $8,000.
Text: A show of righteous patriotism or a display of heedless privilege?

Date: With sunken warship, Russian disinformation faces a test.
Title: Families whose sons were listed as missing after the Russian flagship in the Black Sea sank a week ago are demanding answers in increasing numbers as the Ministry of Defense and top government officials stay silent about the fate of the crew.
Text: Families of missing crew members say the Russian authorities are giving them the runaround after a flagship sank last week in the Black Sea.

Date: Disney vs. Florida
Title: Yesterday, the Florida Senate voted to revoke special benefits that, since the 1960s, have given Disney the ability to essentially self-govern a vast area around its Disney World theme park and issue tax-free municipal bonds. The state’s House, which like its Senate is led by Republicans, is expected to vote for the measure today.
Text: A debate over taxes is rapidly unraveling Florida’s long relationship with Disney, with broader implications for corporate America.

Date: Explosion at Afghan Mosque Kills at Least 10
Title: An explosion at a Shiite mosque in northern Afghanistan on Thursday killed at least 10 people and wounded more than two dozen others, local officials said, adding to the toll of a bloody week for one of the country’s religious minorities.
Text: The blast in Mazar-i-Sharif, one of Afghanistan’s economic hubs, was the latest in a series of attacks on one of its religious minorities and was claimed by an ISIS affiliate.

Date: Fed Chair Powell Calls a Faster Pace of Rate Increases ‘Appropriate’
Title: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, signaled on Thursday that the central bank was prepared to raise interest rates rapidly starting in May as it tries to cool down the economy and prevent fast inflation from becoming a lasting feature.
Text: Jerome Powell spoke at a moment of high inflation and economic uncertainty amid the war in Ukraine.

Date: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen calls for a reshaping of global supply chains that are ‘not secure.’
Title: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Thursday that global supply chains had proved to be unstable amid the pandemic and Russia’s war in Ukraine and called for a reshaping of trade relationships oriented around “trusted partners,” even if it meant higher costs for businesses and consumers.
Text: Policymakers are discussing how to be less reliant on adversarial countries at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.

Date: Biden announces $800 million in new military aid and questions Russia’s hold of Mariupol.
Title: President Biden announced another $800 million in military aid to Ukraine on Thursday, saying it sent an “unmistakable message” to Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin: “He will never succeed in dominating and occupying all of Ukraine.”
Text: President Biden said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would “never succeed in dominating” Ukraine.

Date: The U.S. will outfit five artillery battalions for Ukraine and provide new drones that explode on impact.
Title: The Pentagon is sending an additional $800 million in defense aid to Ukraine that effectively will create five new Ukrainian artillery battalions, and includes more than 120 new drones built specifically for use by Ukraine’s forces. Officials made the announcement in a statement sent to reporters Thursday morning.
Text: The Biden administration is sending dozens of howitzers and 120 drones in the latest $800 million package of military aid.

Date: U.S. Braces for Potential French Election Shockwave
Title: U.S. officials are anxiously watching the French presidential election, aware that the outcome of the vote on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s relations with Europe and reveal dangerous fissures in Western democracy.
Text: An upset victory by the right-wing nationalist Marine Le Pen in the presidential election on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s foreign policy.

Date: Next Phase of War Will Be Pivotal for Russia and Ukraine, U.S. Says
Title: Senior Biden administration officials say they believe that the next four weeks will shape the eventual outcome of Russia’s war in Ukraine, with long-lasting ramifications that will influence the drawing of the map of Europe for decades to come.
Text: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.

Date: A Pivotal Four Weeks
Title: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: With the right weapons, Ukraine might push back Russia’s advance, U.S. officials say.

Date: Calling Off Steel Plant Assault, Putin Prematurely Claims Victory in Mariupol
Title: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed victory in Mariupol on Thursday despite persistent fighting there, publicly calling off an assault on the final Ukrainian stronghold in the devastated city in a stark display of the Kremlin’s desire to present a success to the Russian public.
Text: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.

Date: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
Title: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Date: Ukraine needs up to $7 billion in support per month, Zelensky says.
Title: Ukrainian officials on Thursday met with leaders abroad to call for additional financial support as their country reels from devastating attacks from Russian forces and a disrupted economy.
Text: Ukraine has suffered $550 billion in losses from the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky told the World Bank on Thursday.

Date: Le Pen Closer Than Ever to the French Presidency (and to Putin)
Title: When Europe’s far-right leaders gathered in Madrid in January, they had no problem finding unity on the issues they hold dear, whether cracking down on immigrants or upholding “European Christian ideals.” But as Russian troops massed on the Ukrainian border, they were divided on one issue: the threat posed by President Vladimir V. Putin.
Text: As elections approach Sunday, the far-right candidate is linked to the Russian president by a web of financial ties and a history of support that has hardly dimmed despite the war in Ukraine.

Date: Should We Be More Optimistic About Efforts to Combat Climate Change?
Title: How often do you think about climate change and its impact on the planet? Does the crisis fill you with existential dread? Or do you have faith that humanity will be able to adapt?
Text: Has the existential threat of the climate crisis taken a toll on your mental health? Or do you have a more hopeful view of earth’s future?

Date: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law
Title: The European Union reached a deal on Saturday on landmark legislation that would force Facebook, YouTube and other internet services to combat misinformation, disclose how their services amplify divisive content and stop targeting online ads based on a person’s ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.
Text: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.

Date: One Last Push: Climate Activists to Rally at White House and Across U.S.
Title: Joe Biden was not Vincent Vertuccio’s first choice for president. But as a high school student on Long Island, Mr. Vertuccio organized hundreds of young people to help elect him, driven by a single issue: climate change.
Text: ‘Fight for Our Future’ rallies are planned Saturday for Washington, Atlanta, Phoenix and elsewhere as supporters say time is running out for ambitious climate action.

Date: The Wolf of Crypto and the Confederate Statue Remover: The Week in Narrated Articles
Title: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
Text: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

Date: Joyce DiDonato Wants Music to ‘Build a Paradise for Today’
Title: What are the duties of an artist toward society? As Russia invades Ukraine, as racism persists in the United States, this age-old question remains very much of the moment. And the list of issues to take a political stand on, whether by choice or suggestion, grows ever longer.
Text: The star mezzo-soprano’s album and concert program “Eden” addresses climate change by planting seeds both real and metaphorical.

Date: One Ukrainian War Casualty: The World’s Largest Airplane
Title: The day war broke out, one of Ukraine’s most decorated pilots stepped onto the balcony of his three-story home to watch a battle raging at a nearby airport.
Text: Mriya, the world’s largest aircraft, was destroyed in a pivotal battle at the start of the war. It was a beloved symbol for all of Ukraine but perhaps no one misses it more than its first pilot.

Date: Germany’s economy is expected to contract under a Russian gas embargo.
Title: An embargo on Russian natural gas could cause Germany’s economic output to drop as much as 5 percent this year, the Bundesbank warned on Friday, potentially driving the country into a recession while pushing up already high consumer prices.
Text: The country’s central bank warned that an abrupt end of gas imports from Russia could cause Germany’s economic output to plunge and inflation to jump.

Date: The End of CNN+
Title: Yesterday, Warner Bros. Discovery announced it was shutting down CNN+, the extensively hyped but extremely short-lived streaming service. It will close on April 30, for a total run of less than five weeks. “Well, that was fast,” said Scott Galloway, a professor who was planning to host a CNN+ show on business. Quibi, the ill-fated video platform that was streaming’s previous cautionary tale, lasted seven months.
Text: Its abrupt closure is raising doubts about the crowded field of streaming services.

Date: Why Midterm Election Years Are Tough for the Stock Market
Title: The stock market’s decline and the tightening of financial conditions that have accompanied it since the start of the year are unique to 2022.
Text: These months are historically the weakest for the market in a presidential term. Aside from coincidence, there are several possible explanations.

Date: A Surreal Feel at a Wartime Venice Biennale
Title: “What happened to free speech in Italy?” shouted one of the 50 or so onlookers on Wednesday morning as a security guard stood in front of a lone antiwar protester at the Venice Biennale, trying to block out his message.
Text: While the cool contemporary art crowd strolled among the exhibits, Ukraine was being pummeled by missiles, and there was hardly a Russian in sight.

Date: How Recycling Got So Baffling
Title: A few years ago, my kid and I resolved to reduce our contribution to the landfill. As a test, we set a goal to empty our kitchen trash only once every two weeks.
Text: Plastic waste is everywhere, and today’s recycling systems fall far short of fixing the global mess. Here’s why, and what needs to change.

Date: Skepticism greets a bold Russian claim about war aims, based on its source.
Title: When Gen. Rustam Minnekayev made a sweeping statement on Friday that Russia’s next military aim would be to seize Ukraine’s entire southern coast, many analysts were skeptical, based not only on the claim, but on its source.
Text: A major shift in policy came from an obscure general and not the president or top commander.

Date: Stocks tumble for a third week as jitters over the Fed persist.
Title: Stocks slid on Friday, with the S&P 500 capping a third consecutive weekly decline as Wall Street quickly changed its expectation for how aggressively the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.
Text: Friday was the S&P 500’s worst day since early March. Recent comments from Fed officials have fueled expectations that interest rates will climb far faster than anyone had thought.

Date: Hackers Claim to Target Russian Institutions in Barrage of Cyberattacks and Leaks
Title: Hackers claim to have broken into dozens of Russian institutions over the past two months, including the Kremlin’s internet censor and one of its primary intelligence services, leaking emails and internal documents to the public in an apparent hack-and-leak campaign that is remarkable in its scope.
Text: While the authenticity of leaked data could not be verified, the effort appears to be part of a campaign by hackers opposed to the Kremlin.

Date: Dug in on the front lines, Ukrainian soldiers fight to repel the Russian onslaught.

Date: The War in Ukraine Has Unleashed a New Word

Date: Kono, Yakitori From an Expert, Opens in Manhattan’s Chinatown
Title: Omakase, a type of Japanese meal that leaves the selection of dishes up to the chef, is most often associated with a parade of sushi bites. Mr. Kono was the executive chef of Yakitori Torishin in New York starting in 2006, having spent time working in Japan. Now he is opening his own place, where he will serve yakitori omakase as he presides over grills fueled with the binchotan charcoal frequently used in Japanese cooking. He takes center stage, surrounded on three sides by a dramatically lit counter that seats 14 people for set $165 dinners at 5:30, 6, 8:30 and 9 p.m. (Beverages, tax and tip are extra.) Various parts of organic chickens, including the heart, oyster, soft knee cartilage, tail and tenderloin, are grilled on bamboo skewers as the centerpiece of the meal. Chicken thigh roulade, chicken pâté and soups are also served, with a black sugar crème brûlée as the finale. Wagyu, king crab and Iberico pork are among the optional extras. The restaurant also has a table seating four to six.
