Text: As Russia’s brutal offensive squeezes defenders in eastern Ukraine, Europe’s leaders, in a rebuke to Moscow, made a move they would have rejected before the invasion.

Date: Young soccer players rushed out of Ukraine find themselves in a lonely limbo.
Title: It was in their moment of triumph, when they had beaten their opponents and come together to collect their medals, when some of the boys were overcome with sadness, when the tears welled in their eyes.

Date: In Warsaw Park, Ukraine’s Teen Refugees Hang Out and Hang On
Title: Every afternoon at a park outside a distinctively Stalinesque skyscraper in central Warsaw, scores of Ukrainian teenagers come together. They are young refugees, trying to cope.
Text: Some fled to Poland’s capital alone. All feel deeply uneasy about the future. For the young Ukrainians packing into Poland’s capital, a park offers a place where they can try to cope, together.

Date: Ukraine’s foreign minister sees E.U. candidacy as a crucial step toward joining a ‘liberal empire.’
Title: As the European Union summit began in Brussels on Thursday evening, an aide to Ukraine’s foreign minister tuned into the proceedings on a laptop.
Text: “History has been made,” he said of Ukraine’s being accepted as a candidate for E.U. membership.

Date: Fed Confronts a ‘New World’ of Inflation
Title: a bout of economic soul-searching that could have big implications for the American economy.
Text: Central banks had a longstanding playbook for how inflation worked. In the postpandemic era, all bets are off.

Date: In Russia’s War, China and India Emerge as Financiers
Title: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.
Text: Their purchases of Russian crude are undermining the West’s efforts to isolate the Kremlin and upending the global oil markets.

Date: Her Father Fled the Nazis. She’s the New U.S. Ambassador to Germany.
Title: After Amy Gutmann’s father fled the Nazis in 1934, he swore never to set foot in Germany again. For the rest of his life, he boycotted German goods and only spoke English to his daughter. Germany, he impressed on her when she was growing up, was “very bad.”
Text: For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job, “it’s a mission,” one both professional and personal.

Date: Does Keeping Jurors Unbiased Mean Keeping Everyone Else Quiet?
Title: When Brittany Higgins, a former government staff member, came forward with her allegations of rape, which she said took place inside Australia’s Parliament building, the entire country was transfixed. Her claim that she had been assaulted by a colleague in the defense minister’s office while she was sleeping after a night of drinking prompted protests across Australia by women demanding changes in a male-dominated political culture.
Text: A journalist’s comments prompt the delay of a high-profile criminal trial, and everyone gets a reminder in how careful they need to be in discussing ongoing cases.

Date: Analysis: What the battle for Sievierodonetsk shows about the war.
Title: Wars are not won by retreats. But it is also possible to win the battle and lose the war.
Text: The fighting underscored Russia’s ability to inflict heavy losses on Ukrainian forces, and the importance of Western support for the Ukrainian military.

Date: Commonwealth Meeting in Rwanda Has a Long Agenda. Human Rights Isn’t on It.
Title: Presidents, princes and prime ministers from across the world gathered on Friday in Kigali, the hilly capital of Rwanda, to examine some of the pressing issues facing their nations and the association that unites them: the Commonwealth.
Text: A summit of the organization that was born out of the embers of the British Empire is being held for the first time in the African country, but discussion of the host’s alleged abuses is conspicuously missing.

Date: In Russia’s war over Ukraine, China and India emerge as financiers.
Title: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.

Date: Ukrainian insurgents kill a Kremlin-backed politician in occupied Kherson, part of a wave of attacks.
Title: Ukrainian guerrilla fighters claimed on Friday to have killed a Kremlin-backed politician in the Russian-controlled southern region of Kherson, the latest in a series of attacks aimed at destabilizing the occupation authorities.
Text: A growing guerrilla movement appears to have been fueled by public anger over worsening economic, security and humanitarian conditions.

Date: Heat Waves Around the World Push People and Nations ‘to the Edge’
Title: Millions of Americans are once again in the grips of dangerous heat. Hot air blanketed Europe last weekend, causing parts of France and Spain to feel the way it usually does in July or August. High temperatures scorched northern and central China even as heavy rains caused flooding in the country’s south. Some places in India began experiencing extraordinary heat in March, though the start of the monsoon rains has brought some relief.
Text: Large, simultaneous heat waves are growing more common. China, America, Europe and India have all been stricken recently, and scientists are starting to understand why certain far-flung places get hit at once.

Date: As Russia Chokes Ukraine’s Grain Exports, Romania Tries to Fill In
Title: Stopping at the edge of a vast field of barley on his farm in Prundu, 30 miles outside Romania’s capital city of Bucharest, Catalin Corbea pinched off a spiky flowered head from a stalk, rolled it between his hands, and then popped a seed in his mouth and bit down.
Text: With famine threatening millions, Europe is intent on finding alternatives to one of world’s biggest food exporters, whose landlocked crop is stranded by war.

Date: Serena Williams’s Wimbledon Draw Could Have Been Worse
Title: In her first singles match in a year, Serena Williams could have faced one of the new leaders of the game that she once dominated.
Text: After a year away from singles, she risked drawing the world’s No. 1, Iga Swiatek, in the first round. Instead, she will face a player ranked 113th.

Date: A Sleepy Baltic Rail Line Gets a Geopolitical Wakeup Call
Title: As war rages in Ukraine, fueling ever-growing tensions between NATO and Russia, a sleepy Baltic railway station with no passengers and few trains this week found itself at the center of a perilous new confrontation between East and West.
Text: Russia has accused Lithuania, a NATO member, of choking off the flow of goods to Kaliningrad, its enclave on the Baltic, as part of sanctions over the war in Ukraine. Lithuania says Russia is lying.

Date: E.U. leaders plan for a painful scenario: Russia turning off the gas.
Title: European leaders meeting in Brussels this week were eager to focus on granting Ukraine E.U. candidate status, but have also had to address a pressing problem linked to the war: Russia has slowly been turning off the gas tap.
Text: The tapering of gas has forced Germany, Europe’s economic engine, to escalate its energy emergency protocol and urge residents to conserve power. The next step is rationing.

Date: With New Threats Looming, Canada Commits Billions to Air Defense
Title: Spending on military programs often leads to years of heated political debate and little action in Canada. But the announcement this week that Canada will spend nearly 5 billion Canadian dollars over the next six years on upgrading Norad’s defense systems passed with barely a ripple of controversy.
Text: But it is unclear that giving new capabilities to Norad will be effective against new, superfast missiles.

Date: The Fall of Sievierodonetsk
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Ukraine will withdraw its forces from the largely ruined eastern city.

Date: Russian forces move to encircle Lysychansk, starting with southern villages.
Title: Ukraine’s decision to retreat from Sievierodonetsk, a strategic city in the country’s east, hands Russia another victory in its grinding campaign to seize the Donbas region.

Date: Ukraine Retreats From Embattled City, as Russia Grinds On
Title: After weeks of bloody street fighting and months of withering artillery fire, Ukrainian forces will withdraw from Sievierodonetsk, a city that President Volodymyr Zelensky once said would determine the “fate” of the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
Text: With the withdrawal from Sievierodonetsk, the fighting shifts to neighboring Lysychansk, the last city in the Luhansk region still under Ukrainian control.

Date: U.S.-Led Alliance Faces Frustration, and Pain of its Own, Over Russia Sanctions
Title: Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.
Text: Vladimir V. Putin is making gains in his war on Ukraine while the United States and its allies struggle with soaring energy prices and inflation.

Date: Countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain, even as Putin proves resilient to sanctions.
Title: Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.

Date: Occupied Mariupol is suffering deeply, its mayor says.
Title: Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that became emblematic of the savagery of Russia’s military campaign, is now suffering deeply under Russian rule, according to the city’s mayor.

Date: Coal Dust and Methane Below, Russian Bombs Above
Title: When Aleksander Maryinych enters a metal cage and descends into darkness with dozens of other miners for his six-hour shifts, the concussive thumps of an artillery war are replaced by the clatter of rail carts and the grind of machinery carving deep into the earth.
Text: The war has added a new threat to the dangerous lives of miners in eastern Ukraine.

Date: Belarus’s Leader, ‘Europe’s Last Dictator,’ Burnishes Links to Russia
Title: In the weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine, it held joint military drills with its neighbor and ally Belarus, massing tens of thousands of soldiers along the Ukrainian border even as the two countries’ leaders denied reports that the Kremlin was planning to go to war.
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia  met with President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Saturday amid questions over how far Minsk will allow itself to be drawn into the war.

Date: The Quest to Beat High Gas Prices
Title: “I SOLD MY GIRLFRIENDS CAR CAUSE GAS PRICES ARE HIGH 😳” reads the caption on the video Justice Alexander posted online this spring. In the clip, Mr. Alexander, a content creator in Los Angeles, sits atop a horse and declares that he will now travel on horseback.
Text: From changing their work hours to driving farther in search of cheaper deals, people have been making crafty calculations to grapple with expensive gasoline.

Date: Once Again, Tennis Is Disrupted by Politics
Title: If he had it to do over, Brad Gilbert would never have played a professional tennis tournament in South Africa while the country was embroiled in apartheid.
Text: The sport has a long history of disputes, especially over apartheid. This year Wimbledon has banned Russian and Belarusian players.

Date: Russia hits Ukraine with over 40 missiles, including in areas that were recently spared.
Title: As intense battles raged in eastern Ukraine and Russian forces pressed to cut off the supply lines for thousands of Ukrainian soldiers, Moscow unleashed more than 40 missiles on targets across the country on Saturday morning, including in areas in the north and west that have been largely spared in recent weeks.

Date: For a Kyiv techno collective, ‘now everything is about politics.’
Title: parties in factories, skate parks and even an abandoned Soviet restaurant that united thousands on the dance floor to a soundtrack of experimental electronic music.
Text: “This war has destroyed the statement that art could be outside politics,” the group’s booking and communications manager said.

Date: Biden Signs Gun Bill Into Law, Ending Years of Stalemate
Title: President Biden on Saturday signed into law a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms and increase investments in the nation’s mental health system, ending nearly three decades of gridlock in Washington over how to address gun violence in the United States.
Text: The bill is the most significant gun measure to clear Congress in nearly three decades, though it falls short of more restrictive gun control proposals that Democrats favor.

Date: Mayor of Embattled Southern Ukrainian City Urges All Residents to Leave
Title: The mayor of this embattled southern port city, under attack from Russian forces since the start of the war, has called for “everyone who wants to survive” to leave, because “it’s not clear when all this will be over.”
Text: The request by the Mykolaiv official was somewhat surprising, given that the city’s combative, never-say-die spirit has become a symbol of Ukrainian resistance.

Date: Russia Unleashes a Missile Barrage, While Inching Ahead in Eastern Ukraine
Title: From the skies above Belarus to the north and the waters of the Black Sea to the south, Russian forces unleashed a fusillade of cruise missiles across Ukraine on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said, in one of the most widespread and coordinated aerial assaults in weeks.
Text: Some of the missiles were launched from Belarus, whose leader is meeting Saturday with the Russian president.

Date: Commando Network Coordinates Flow of Weapons in Ukraine, Officials Say
Title: As Russian troops press ahead with a grinding campaign to seize eastern Ukraine, the nation’s ability to resist the onslaught depends more than ever on help from the United States and its allies — including a stealthy network of commandos and spies rushing to provide weapons, intelligence and training, according to U.S. and European officials.
Text: A secretive operation involving U.S. Special Operations forces hints at the scale of the effort to assist Ukraine’s still outgunned military.

Date: A New Task for Biden: Readying Allies for a Long Conflict in Ukraine
Title: When President Biden met his Western allies in Europe three months ago, the world was rallying behind Ukraine, and NATO suddenly had a new sense of purpose — its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.
Text: In March, talk of victory was in the air. Now, maintaining unity against President Vladimir V. Putin is looking harder, with President Biden heading to Germany and Spain to rally Europe.

Date: Commonwealth’s Fissures Exposed at Week of Meetings
Title: As the leaders of the Commonwealth wrapped up a week of closed-door meetings, panel discussions and formal dinners on Saturday in Rwanda, this “family of nations” still stood at a crossroads, with questions remaining about its usefulness and whether it can reinvent itself for the 21st century.
Text: This year’s summit for the group of nations came as they grappled with the place of the monarchy, and as many were forging connections with powers like China and Russia.

Date: A Year Away, a New Coach and the Same Goal: Winning Wimbledon
Title: At first glance, it certainly looked like business as usual at Wimbledon on Saturday.
Text: Ahead of her 21st Wimbledon appearance, Serena Williams discussed coming back from a tough injury, but steered away from political discussions.

Date: Here is what foreign-policy experts are discussing ahead of the G7 meeting.
Title: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, this year’s Group of 7 summit was supposed to provide an opportunity to change gears from typical geopolitics and finance, and focus on the future. The top themes were meant to be climate, public health amid the coronavirus pandemic and equity around the globe.

Date: Biden’s new task is to ready allies for a long conflict in Ukraine.
Title: its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.
Text: President Biden will be trying to unite his allies on new ways to isolate Moscow.

Date: Rising food and fuel prices loom over the summit.
Title: Hovering over the Group of 7 meeting and the NATO summit that follows it is a perilous moment for the global economy, probably the most tenuous since the 2008-09 financial crisis.

Date: The U.S. and Britain will ban imports of gold from Russia.
Title: The United States and other Group of 7 countries will ban imports of gold from Russia, seeking to undercut a key source of revenue for Moscow as it wages war in Ukraine, President Biden said on Sunday as G7 leaders gathered in the Bavarian Alps.
Text: President Biden announced the decision before the start of a G7 summit meeting in Germany.

Date: As G7 leaders meet, Russia sends a message with missile attacks.
Title: Russia unleashed a new round of missiles at Kyiv on Sunday, the first attack on the Ukrainian capital in weeks, an apparent show of defiance as a summit of the world’s biggest democracies opened on Sunday with new steps to isolate Moscow.

Date: Ukraine War’s Latest Victim? The Fight Against Climate Change.
Title: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine seemed like an unexpected opportunity for environmentalists, who had struggled to focus the world’s attention on the kind of energy independence that renewable resources can offer. With the West trying to wean itself from Russian oil and gas, the argument for solar and wind power seemed stronger than ever.
Text: As leaders of the Group of 7 gather in Germany, the scramble to replace Russian fossil fuels is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed.

Date: Past G7 summits have produced some memorable photos.
Title: International summits are usually highly scripted, and not meant to produce candid moments. But Group of 7 conferences have occasionally offered telling snapshots of the relationships among global leaders.

Date: Missile Strike in Kyiv Rattles Residents After Weeks of Quiet
Title: Olha and her husband, Roman, stood on a concrete platform, carefully avoiding debris and shards of glass, staring at the smoldering building that contained the apartment they moved into one year ago.
Text: The strike on Sunday morning shook many out of the relative sense of security that has prevailed in Ukraine’s capital since the Russians were pushed out of its periphery in early April.

Date: Russian Strike on Kyiv Looms Over G7 Summit
Title: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations said Sunday they would stop buying gold from Moscow and discussed a new American proposal to undercut its oil revenues, even as Russian forces rained missiles on Kyiv for the first time in weeks. The dueling escalation underscored how the war in Ukraine has consumed global politics and the world economy.
Text: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.

Date: Novak Djokovic Has Prepared His Way. So Has Rafael Nadal.
Title: While the French Open has long been Rafael Nadal time, Wimbledon has become Novak Djokovic time.
Text: By design, Djokovic usually does not play grass-court events before Wimbledon, and he has won five times with that tactic. Nadal, necessitated by injury, is on the same track this year.

Date: As Wimbledon Begins, an Era of Sports Free of Bans and Boycotts Ends
Title: For roughly three decades, making sure athletes participated in the biggest events regardless of the world’s never-ending military and political battles has been a nearly sacrosanct tenet of international sports.
Text: For decades, sports has avoided punishing athletes for the actions of their countries. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has put an end to that.

Date: Russia Misses Bond Deadline, Signaling Its First Default on Foreign Debt Since 1918
Title: Russia missed a deadline for making bond payments on Sunday, a move signaling its first default on international debt in more than a century, after Western sanctions thwarted the government’s efforts to pay foreign investors. The lapse adds to efforts to seal Moscow off from global capital markets for years.
Text: Economic sanctions that blocked bond payments have strengthened efforts to seal off Moscow from global markets.

Date: U.S. officials say the G7 is close to an agreement on price caps on Russian oil.
Title: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations are close to an agreement in principle to begin the process of potentially imposing price caps on Russian oil and are set to impose other new economic penalties on Moscow to support Ukraine, Biden administration officials said on Monday.

Date: Europe and the U.S. court India to join efforts to punish Russia.
Title: As Ukraine’s allies seek to broaden the coalition of nations against Russia, the United States and Europe are working to persuade India to abandon its neutral stance in the war in Ukraine.
Text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has maintained a neutral stance on the war.

Date: Civilians should immediately evacuate a Ukrainian city that is under fire, a regional official warned.
Title: Civilians should immediately leave the Ukrainian city of Lysychansk, the region’s governor said on Monday — an indication of the gathering pace of the Russian onslaught in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
Text: Residents of Lysychansk, across the river from a city that fell to Russian control last week, should leave over “the real threat to life and health,” the region’s military governor said.

Date: Abroad, Jacinda Ardern Is a Star. At Home, She’s Losing Her Shine.
Title: Abroad, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand remains a leading liberal light. During a recent trip to the United States, she delivered the commencement address at Harvard, cracked jokes with Stephen Colbert and met in the Oval Office with President Biden. At each stop, she highlighted her successes in passing gun restrictions and handling the pandemic.
Text: New problems in New Zealand like inflation and gang violence and old problems like unaffordable housing have sent her polling numbers to new lows as an election looms next year.

Date: What the ban on Russia’s gold imports means for its increasingly isolated economy.
Title: The decision over the weekend to ban the purchase of newly mined and refined gold from Russia is the latest effort by the United States, Britain and their allies to notch up the wave of sanctions concentrated on Russia in response to its four-month-old invasion of Ukraine.
Text: The move by the United States, Britain and others builds on steps to cut off Russia from the international financial system.

Date: After a weekend of strikes, sirens bring anxiety even in Ukraine’s safest cities.
Title: The all-too-familiar blare of an air raid siren signaled rockets within striking distance of this city in western Ukraine on Monday afternoon. It was the fifth time in less than 48 hours.
Text: The dozens of the missiles launched by Russian forces into Ukraine over the weekend have raised anxiety in Lviv, even in the relative peace of the country’s northwest.

Date: A missile strike hits a crowded shopping center in central Ukraine.
Title: Hundreds of people were out shopping, chatting and meeting with friends in a shopping mall in central Ukraine on Monday, a rare moment of normalcy amid the horror of war. Then a Russian missile struck.
Text: Videos of the site, near the railway station in the central city of Kremenchuk, showed a fire raging as emergency workers frantically attempted to extinguish the flames.

Date: Russian Court Says Brittney Griner’s Trial Will Begin on Friday
Title: A Russian court said the trial for the U.S. basketball star Brittney Griner will begin on Friday and she will remain in custody until it ends, her lawyer, Aleksandr Boikov, said on Monday.
Text: Ms. Griner, a seven-time W.N.B.A. all-star, has been in custody since February.

Date: The G7 ponders capping oil prices to deny Russia revenues. How would it work?
Title: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations meeting in Germany, seeking a new way to throttle Russia’s finances while limiting the harm to Western economies, are discussing imposing a ceiling on the price paid for Russian oil. Details of the plan are still being discussed, but the idea is to limit how much Russia can earn from the oil it sells while still keeping markets well supplied.
Text: The goal is a way to tighten Russia’s finances while preventing big rises in oil prices. But it’s unclear if such a plan could succeed.

Date: At a Boarding School in Ukraine, Displaced Children Long for Home
Title: In the arched dining hall of a former boarding school in Lviv, Kamila Horbachova and other teenage girls set out dishes, as younger children scrambled into seats and then tucked into dinners handed out by the cafeteria staff.
Text: Many left their parents behind when they were evacuated from the country’s east. Now they wrestle with the trauma of a conflict that has consumed much of their young lives.

Date: Spotting the Fault Lines in NATO’s United Front
Title: After the collapse of the Soviet Union, some asked whether NATO had any real reason to exist. But Russia’s invasion of Ukraine gave new urgency to NATO as a defensive alliance aimed at deterring Moscow.
Text: The alliance is supporting Ukraine’s defense against Russia with money and arms, but its summit in Madrid this week will involve some difficult talks, including about where to put troops.

Date: Global Food Crisis Tests Western Resolve to Retain Russia Sanctions
Title: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Text: With a food shortage threatening to create widespread famine, Western countries face a tough choice as sanctions exacerbate the problem.

Date: New Ways to Try to Punish Russia
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: G7 leaders are considering putting price caps on Russian oil.

Date: Lithuania blames Russia for cyberattacks, citing threats over cargo restrictions.
Title: Just days after Moscow threatened retaliation against Lithuania for placing restrictions on cargo traffic to the isolated Russian territory of Kaliningrad, computer hackers “linked to the Russian state” attacked dozens of Lithuanian government and private organizations, the Baltic nation’s deputy defense minister said.
Text: Hackers have struck dozens of Lithuanian government and private organizations, according to a Lithuanian official.

Date: U.S. Urges New Tactic to Curb Putin’s War Machine and Lower Fuel Prices
Title: Four months into Russia’s invasion, unprecedented Western economic retaliation and military aid to Ukraine have not curbed Vladimir V. Putin’s ability or apparent determination to wage war, leaving leaders of the world’s wealthiest democracies grasping for new ways to deter him.
Text: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.

Date: After Monday’s mall airstrike, shocked residents grapple with the destruction, the dead and the missing.
Title: Late into the evening on Monday night, the Amstar shopping mall was still smoking as hundreds of firefighters and emergency workers sought to clear away the rubble.
Text: “The worst thing is that this is a shopping mall,” said a town official. “Any of us could have been here.”

Date: The New (Cushy Seats) and the Familiar (Novak, Nerves) Mix at Wimbledon
Title: It is about tradition this year at Wimbledon on the 100th anniversary of Centre Court, but as the defending men’s singles champion Novak Djokovic walked back onto the grass on Monday to launch this year’s tournament, it was also about change.
Text: One hundred years after the opening of Centre Court, it’s a season of change at the All England Club, what with the barring of Russian players and a new set of green doors.

Date: Quotation of the Day: Longing for Home, Displaced Children Wrestle With War’s Trauma
Title: they have been living in a state of war for eight years. They know what loss is, what death is.”
Text: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 28, 2022.

Date: NATO says it will significantly increase troops assigned to its eastern flank.
Title: NATO is set to approve its biggest overhaul of its defenses since the Cold War, significantly increasing the number of troops assigned to defend the alliance’s eastern flank and making a major commitment to position heavy military equipment there.

Date: The NATO summit in Madrid could see fissures and debate beneath a semblance of unity.
Title: After the collapse of the Soviet Union, some asked whether NATO had any real reason to exist. But Russia’s invasion of Ukraine gave new urgency to NATO as a defensive alliance aimed at deterring a bellicose Moscow.

Date: A cap on the price of Russian oil comes with many questions.
Title: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations meeting in Germany, seeking a new way to throttle Russia’s finances while limiting the harm to Western economies, are discussing imposing a ceiling on the price paid for Russian oil.
Text: The idea is to limit how much Russia can earn from the oil it sells while still keeping markets well supplied.

Date: G7 Leaders Promise $4.5 Billion to Address Global Hunger Caused by War in Ukraine
Title: The United States and its Group of 7 allies on Tuesday pledged to spend $4.5 billion this year to help ensure food security around the globe, seeking to counter global food shortages caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Text: The planned commitment, more than half of it from the U.S., reflects worldwide alarm at shortages in wheat and sunflower oil caused by Russia’s invasion.

Date: Less Takeout, More Produce Swapping: How Inflation Is Altering People’s Behavior
Title: Americans are suffering from sticker shock.
Text: From driving fewer miles to downgrading vacations, Americans are making meaningful changes to their spending. Here’s how five households are coping with the highest inflation in decades.

Date: On Front Lines, Communication Breakdowns Prove Costly for Ukraine
Title: In the waning days of the battle for the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk, a Ukrainian National Guard sergeant had a problem: His platoon’s flank was exposed and he needed to tell his men the Russians were approaching.
Text: with sometimes deadly results.

Date: Berrettini Out of Wimbledon as Coronavirus Enters the Draw
Title: Matteo Berrettini, a finalist at Wimbledon last year, withdrew from the tournament on Tuesday after testing positive for the coronavirus.
Text: The exit of Matteo Berrettini, who reached the men’s singles final last year, came one day after Marin Cilic withdrew after also testing positive for the virus.

Date: ‘This is our 1937 moment,’ the U.K.’s new army chief says of the war.
Title: The British Army must act rapidly to prevent any further military action by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia beyond the borders of Ukraine, the force’s new head said on Tuesday, adding that Britain must be ready to defend NATO territory if necessary.
Text: Gen. Patrick Sanders, alluding to Western Europe’s failure to confront Nazi Germany, said that Britain must not allow Russia’s military action to expand into NATO territory.

Date: Who’s Profiting From Demand for Plan B?
Title: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, many women have been rushing to stock up on emergency contraception pills, in hopes of exerting more control over their bodies, or because they’re worried that the products could be restricted. (Birth control remains legal across the United States.) Drugstores have found themselves in short supply of the pills, and some are limiting purchases.
Text: A rush to stock up on emergency contraception could mean huge profits for the investors behind the well-known morning-after pill.

Date: In Russia Crisis, India Tries to Balance Geopolitics and Economics
Title: When Russia first invaded Ukraine, the United States warned India against buying more Russian oil, saying that New Delhi could face “consequences.” Now the West is softening its stance, emphasizing that India doesn’t need to choose sides.
Text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who attended the G7 meeting, is also trying to position India as the voice of poorer nations, arguing that sanctions hurt developing countries the most.

Date: ‘I Was Flying Headfirst’: A Shopping Trip Shattered by a Missile
Title: For Lyudmila Mykhailets, it was a simple trip to the mall with her husband, Nikolai, to check the prices of a new blender at the Comfy.ua store. In an instant, it turned into something horrific.
Text: Survivors of the Russian strike that hit a busy mall in central Ukraine, killing at least 18, described the moment that tore their lives apart.

Date: One way to make a huge difference
Title: On Tuesday leaders from the Group of 7 industrialized nations are wrapping up a summit in Germany, and climate was supposed to be one of the main items on the agenda. Unfortunately, it didn’t turn out that way. The meeting was dominated by the war in Ukraine, very much at the expense of climate.
Text: The World Bank is in a unique position to help developing countries prepare for climate change. Here are two things critics say it could do better, and one they say it shouldn’t do at all.

Date: A Ukrainian official who revealed details about life in Russian-controlled Kherson has been arrested, officials say.
Title: After Russian forces captured the southern city of Kherson, much of what the outside world knew about life under Moscow’s rule came from the city’s mayor, who described a world of repression, insecurity and the mass detainment of hundreds of people.
Text: The mayor was arrested shortly after arriving at the municipal headquarters, where he had continued to work despite being ousted from office, local officials said.

Date: How Has the War Changed Your Worldview?
Title: The Russian assault on Ukraine is now in its fifth month, with no end in sight.
Text: We want to hear from you.

Date: Giuliani at Center of Georgia’s Trump Investigation
Title: Rudolph W. Giuliani has emerged as a central figure in a Georgia criminal investigation of efforts by Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn his election loss in the state, with prosecutors questioning witnesses last week before a special grand jury about Mr. Giuliani’s appearances before state legislative panels after the 2020 vote, the witnesses said.
Text: Of all the legal threats Rudy Giuliani faces, the criminal inquiry into efforts to reverse the 2020 Georgia election may be the most dire.

Date: Disney Board Renews Bob Chapek as C.E.O.
Title: For months, Hollywood has been engaged in a guessing game about Bob Chapek’s future as Disney’s chief executive, with detractors contending that missteps had sealed his fate with Disney’s board: His reign would soon be over.
Text: The company has faced major challenges recently, leading some to question whether Mr. Chapek would last. His contract was extended three years.

Date: To Counter Putin, Biden Tries to Assemble an Upside-Down Cartel
Title: President Biden is leading an effort to manipulate the oil market at a scale the world has rarely seen, embracing cartel-like tactics in an aggressive but risky attempt to undermine Russia’s war effort in Ukraine.
Text: President Biden led his Group of 7 counterparts to agree on a plan that would cap the price of Russian oil, a daunting goal that risks the Kremlin restricting supply even further.

Date: Finland and Sweden make security pledges to win Turkey’s acceptance of their NATO membership bids.
Title: NATO leaders will formally invite Finland and Sweden to join the alliance on Wednesday after Turkey lifted its veto on their membership, NATO’s secretary-general said Tuesday evening, clearing the way for what would be one of the most significant expansions of the alliance in decades.
Text: The historic deal underscored how the war in Ukraine has backfired for Russia, which has tried to weaken the Atlantic alliance.

Date: Turkey Lifts its Veto at NATO
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: Erdogan drops his opposition to Finland and Sweden joining the alliance.

Date: Bomb threats paralyze the Lithuanian government. The police suspect that Russia is behind them.
Title: A flood of fake bomb threats briefly paralyzed the work of government ministries, courts and police stations in Lithuania on Tuesday, raising fears that Russia was escalating pressure on the Baltic NATO country in retaliation for restrictions on freight traffic to an isolated Russian territory.

Date: In Blow to Putin, Turkey Won’t Bar Sweden and Finland From NATO
Title: NATO’s top official said Tuesday that Turkey had dropped its objections to the membership of Sweden and Finland, two historically nonaligned nations that, alarmed by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have asked to join the military alliance.
Text: The change was a victory for President Biden and a setback to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who had justified the Ukraine invasion as a warning against NATO’s expansion.

Date: Zelensky urges the U.N. to label Russia a terrorist state over a missile strike on a shopping mall.
Title: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday, calling for the organization to brand Russia a terrorist state and dispatch investigators to inspect a missile attack on a shopping mall a day earlier in the city of Kremenchuk.

Date: After Rapes by Russian Soldiers, a Painful Quest for Justice
Title: Every day, Viktoriya has to walk past the house where she was raped by a Russian soldier the same age as her teenage son.
Text: Women who were attacked in a village near Kyiv yearn for justice. “I want them to be punished,” said one victim. But Ukrainian officials face daunting challenges in prosecuting such crimes.

Date: NATO formally invites Finland and Sweden to join the alliance.
Title: NATO leaders on Wednesday formally invited Finland and Sweden to join the alliance, one day after Turkey dropped its objections to their membership, clearing the way for what would be one of the most significant expansions of the alliance in decades.
Text: The historic deal underscores how the war in Ukraine has backfired for President Vladimir V. Putin.

Date: Who Is Harmony Tan, the Player Who Beat Serena Williams at Wimbledon?
Title: The matchup seemed lopsided on paper.
Text: Tan, 24, had merely hoped to take a game or two off Williams, a seven-time Wimbledon singles champion. Instead, she won and has a chance to reach the third round of a major for the first time.

Date: Liquefied Natural Gas Comes to Europe’s Rescue. But for How Long?
Title: The placid waters near the entrance to the River Medway look more suited for sailboats and other pleasure craft, but some of the biggest ships in the world twist their way to a pier here.
Text: Chilled gas is a lifeline, but the fuel, largely from the United States, may set back climate ambitions and prove a costly, short-term solution.

Date: The Vanishing Moderate Democrat
Title: Early last year, as Democrats were preparing to control the White House and Congress for the first time in a decade, Josh Gottheimer met with Nancy Pelosi to discuss their party’s message. Sitting in the House speaker’s office in the U.S. Capitol, he opened up the YouTube app on his iPhone. There was something he wanted to show her.
Text: Their positions are popular. So why are they going extinct?

Date: ‘It is not at all safe’: Cities across Ukraine suffer a steady stream of civilian casualties.
Title: After an airstrike leveled a shopping center in central Ukraine this week, attention once again turned to the large human cost of the war far from the battlefield.
Text: Despite a Russian claims to focus on military infrastructure, civilian sites have increasingly been destroyed.

Date: The U.S. moves closer to selling F-16s to Turkey.
Title: The United States on Wednesday signaled a new willingness to sell upgraded F-16 fighter jets to Turkey, moving closer to satisfying the ally’s longstanding request a day after Turkey dropped its opposition to efforts by Finland and Sweden to join the NATO alliance.
Text: A day after Turkey dropped its opposition to Sweden and Finland joining NATO, a Biden administration official said that Washington “supports Turkey’s modernization of its fighter fleet.”

Date: Why do Finland and Sweden appear headed toward swift NATO membership while Ukraine isn’t?
Title: With Finland and Sweden now racing toward NATO membership, the prospect of the two Nordic countries joining the seven-decade-old Atlantic alliance is raising a pressing question in Kyiv and beyond: Why them and not Ukraine?
Text: The imperative to seek NATO membership is written into Ukraine’s Constitution. But even President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that it may never happen.

Date: The U.S. accused Chinese companies of supporting Russia’s military.
Title: The United States has accused five Chinese companies of violating sanctions against Russia by continuing to support Russia’s military, and took action this week to block them from buying American technology, the Commerce Department said.
Text: The Commerce Department imposed trade restrictions on five businesses that it says violated sanctions.

Date: Global central bankers confront a changed inflation picture, and pledge to respond.
Title: Three of the world’s top central bankers set out a grim prediction on Wednesday: The forces that weighed down inflation for decades before the onset of the pandemic may never return, forcing policymakers to keep up efforts to cool down their economies in a bid to get rapid price increases back under control.
Text: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, and his counterparts in Britain and the European Union spoke at a conference in Portugal.

Date: Ukraine announces largest prisoner exchange yet, including Mariupol fighters.
Title: Ukrainian officials announced the largest prisoner exchange since Russia’s invasion, saying 144 soldiers were being returned to Ukraine, including dozens who defended Mariupol, a southern port city that became a symbol of Russian repression and Ukrainian defiance.
Text: Officials said 144 Ukrainian soldiers, many of them seriously injured, were released in an exchange for the same number of Russian and proxy forces.

Date: Putin wants to take most of Ukraine, but a quick breakthrough is unlikely, the top U.S. intelligence official says.
Title: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia still aims to take most of Ukraine, but a breakthrough in the country’s east to other major cities beyond the Donbas remains unlikely in the short term even as Moscow’s forces consolidate their gains, the top American intelligence official said on Wednesday.

Date: Ex-Giuliani Associate Is Sentenced to Prison in Campaign Finance Scheme
Title: When Lev Parnas was arrested in 2019, he was known mainly as a minor presence in Republican political circles: someone who traded on connections with allies of Donald J. Trump, including the president’s personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to gain access to other Republican candidates.
Text: Lev Parnas, a Soviet-born businessman, tried to use campaign donations funneled from Russia to advance a cannabis business.

Date: Old Foe for NATO
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: The alliance says that Moscow is once again its primary adversary.

Date: A More Muscular NATO Emerges as West Confronts Russia and China
Title: Faced with a newly aggressive Russia, NATO leaders on Wednesday outlined a muscular new vision that names Moscow as the military alliance’s primary adversary but also, for the first time, declares China to be a strategic “challenge.”
Text: It is a fundamental shift for a military alliance born in the Cold War and scrambling to respond to a newly reshaped world.

Date: The U.N. has documented at least 3,924 Ukrainian civilian deaths in the war.
Title: After visiting numerous bombing sites and detention centers, conducting hundreds of interviews and scouring piles of documents, the United Nations has put a number to the human cost of Russia’s war in Ukraine: at least 3,924 civilians dead as of May 15, of whom 193 were children, and 4,444 injured.

Date: Patient and Confident, Putin Shifts Out of Wartime Crisis Mode
Title: Early in his war against Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared tense, angry and even disoriented. He spent days out of the public eye, threatened the West with nuclear strikes, and lashed out at antiwar Russians as “scum.”
Text: Cloistered and spouting grievances at the start of the war on Ukraine, the Russian leader now appears publicly, projecting the aura of a calm, paternalistic leader shielding his people from the dangers of the world.

Date: Brittney Griner’s Trial in Russia Is Starting, and Likely to End in a Conviction
Title: More than four months after she was first detained, the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner is expected to appear in a Russian courtroom on Friday for the start of a trial on drug charges that legal experts said was all but certain to end in a conviction despite the clamor in the United States for her release.
Text: Courts in Russia heavily favor the prosecution, experts said, pointing to a prisoner swap as perhaps the W.N.B.A. star’s best chance to come home.

Date: As Dockworkers Near Contract’s End, Many Others Have a Stake
Title: David Alvarado barreled south along the highway, staring through the windshield of his semi truck toward the towering cranes along the coastline.
Text: West Coast longshoremen and port operators say they’re determined to reach an agreement, but truckers and retailers relying on cargo are uneasy.

Date: After Stock Market’s Worst Start in 50 Years, Some See More Pain Ahead
Title: Wall Street set records in the first half of the year, none of them good.
Text: At the halfway point of the year, it’s been a historically horrible time for stocks. Bonds are in bad shape, too.

Date: Vitaliy Kim, Master Motivator and Symbol of Ukraine’s Resistance
Title: To win the war, says Vitaliy Kim, you need to love the war. “Love what you are doing, reconcile with the situation you are in, find something good in every circumstance, in small victories, in results.”
Text: Applying the lessons of taekwondo, the regional military leader has rallied the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.

Date: OPEC Plus lifts its oil output target to prepandemic levels.
Title: Officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil-producing countries decided on Thursday to confirm the decision taken last month to lift output by 648,000 barrels per day in August.
Text: The group confirmed its decision to restore production to about 44 million barrels a day. But difficult questions remain about its relationships with Russia and the United States.

Date: In Munich, Young Directors Offer Horrors Both Real and Fantastical
Title: At the end of a recent performance of “Bad Roads” here, the play’s Ukrainian director, Tamara Trunova, thanked the audience for staying for the entire 180-minute production, a harrowing succession of vignettes set in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, which Russia invaded in 2014, eight years before it undertook a larger war against Ukraine.
Text: The Radikal Jung festival transports theatergoers to Russia’s 2014 invasion of eastern Ukraine and an American high school in the Middle Ages.

Date: China’s Leader Hails a Hong Kong ‘Reborn From Ashes’ Amid Crackdown
Title: Since the pandemic erupted in 2020, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has been hunkered down in a virus-free bubble within his country’s closed borders. On Thursday, he left the safe confines of the mainland for the first time, arriving in Hong Kong for a tightly scripted visit aimed at reinforcing his authority over the city.
Text: Before Xi Jinping’s tightly controlled appearance, Hong Kong sent officials, diplomats and others to hotels for days of isolation and Covid tests.

Date: How Long Will Europe Support Ukraine?
Title: At the start of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, European leaders painted the battle in stark moral terms, imposing harsh sanctions against Russia and talking about President Volodymyr Zelensky as a hero.
Text: The continent’s leaders increasingly want to understand how the war with Russia might end.

Date: Ukraine drives Russian forces from Snake Island, a setback for Moscow.
Title: Russian troops have withdrawn from Snake Island in the Black Sea after repeated assaults by Ukrainian forces, a move that is a setback for Moscow’s forces and possibly undermines their control over vital shipping lanes for grain in the Black Sea.
Text: The retreat came after sustained Ukrainian attacks, including with newly arrived Western weapons, made it impossible for Russian forces to hold the island.

Date: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
Title: President Biden issued a grim warning to Americans after Russian troops invaded Ukraine in February: standing up to President Vladimir V. Putin could hurt the U.S. economy. “I will not pretend this will be painless,” he said in remarks delivered in the East Room of the White House.
Text: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Date: Income and Spending Lag Behind Inflation, a Sign of Economic Fragility
Title: Americans’ income and spending failed to keep pace with rising prices in May, the latest sign that the fastest inflation in a generation is chipping away at the bedrock of the economic recovery.
Text: After the latest monthly consumer data, some analysts expect a second straight quarter of decline in the U.S. gross domestic product.

Date: To Save Its Honey Industry, Australia Is Killing Bees by the Millions
Title: The first step is pouring gasoline into the beehive. Then it’s time to wait. The job is finished when the hive is burned the next day.
Text: Australia is the only major honey-producing country that has so far managed to contain the spread of a mite fatal to bees. That distinction is now in peril.

Date: Court Decision Leaves Biden With Few Tools to Combat Climate Change
Title: One by one, the tools available to President Biden to fight climate change are being stripped away.
Text: A Supreme Court ruling, combined with an energy crunch and intraparty politics, makes it nearly impossible for President Biden to achieve his climate goals.

Date: A Party Crawl With Pussy Riot’s Nadya Tolokonnikova
Title: “I’m a super-introvert,” said Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, one of the founding members of Pussy Riot, as the elevator zoomed to the Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of Rockefeller Center, where the NFT Now gala was in full swing on June 21.
Text: At 21, she was a founding member of the Russian anti-government punk collective. At 22, she was imprisoned. A decade later, she’s still fighting, this time using cryptocurrency to help her subvert the system.

Date: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
Title: President Biden vowed on Thursday that the United States and NATO would support Ukraine for as long as necessary to repel Russia’s invasion, despite waves of economic pain rolling through world markets and voters’ homes, saying it was the Kremlin that had miscalculated in its aggression, and not the West in opposing it.
Text: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.

Date: Putin Regains His Swagger
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: The Russian president seems to be back to his former self.

Date: Missile Strikes on Ukraine Kill at Least 21 Near Odesa
Title: At least 21 people were killed and dozens were injured when Russian missiles struck a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port of Odesa early Friday, Ukrainian officials said.
Text: The strikes hit a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port city of Odesa.

Date: Russia Hints at Linking Griner’s Case to Fate of ‘Merchant of Death’
Title: She is an American professional basketball star, accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage.
Text: Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer, is serving a 25-year prison sentence in the United States.

Date: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
Title: Dressed in black, the actors moved around a sparse rehearsal room preparing a new play — the story of a dissident Ukrainian who died in a Russian prison camp decades ago. As they took a break, they gathered in a circle with their arms around each other, laughing and chattering.
Text: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.

Date: Russia hints at linking Griner’s case to Viktor Bout, a Russian known as the ‘Merchant of Death.’
Title: She is an American professional basketball star, accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage.

Date: Pictures of Brittney Griner in custody offer few clues to her well-being.
Title: Photos of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner being led through a courthouse outside Moscow were released this week before her trial on drug charges that is set to begin on Friday, giving the Western world a rare glimpse of her after four months of being detained in Russia.
Text: Images of the W.N.B.A. star released since her arrest in an airport near Moscow on Feb. 17 have been scrutinized for clues about her mental and physical health.

Date: ‘So Stressed Out’: Gas Prices Force Many to Rethink Driving, and Spending
Title: Most Americans would gladly pay the $4.29 for a gallon of regular gas Buc-ee’s was charging this week on Interstate 10 between Houston and San Antonio, more than 50 cents below the national average.
Text: As summer trips beckon, some are traveling less, at least by car. And those candy bars at the convenience store may find fewer takers.

Date: Griner’s supporters are imploring the Biden administration to secure her release.
Title: Brittney Griner’s family and supporters are increasingly imploring President Biden and the U.S. government to secure her release amid continuing fears that she could be used by Russia in the geopolitical jousting over its war in Ukraine.
Text: The agent of the basketball star Brittney Griner recently coordinated a letter to President Biden urging his administration to strike a deal for her release.

Date: Eurozone inflation rises to 8.6 percent, the highest ever, driven by energy prices.
Title: Record energy prices drove the inflation rate for the countries using the common European currency to 8.6 percent over the year through June, as the fallout of the war in Ukraine and the economic conflict it has set off between Russia and Western Europe continued to bite.
Text: Nearly half the countries in the currency area have now reached double-digit inflation.

Date: Putin moves to seize a large gas venture in Russia’s Far East.
Title: Russia is moving to take over an important natural gas joint venture, putting the investments of Shell and two Japanese energy trading companies at risk in a seizure of a significant foreign investment.
Text: Shell and two Japanese companies, Mitsui and Mitsubishi, are minority shareholders in the Sakhalin-2 joint venture.

Date: Summer Reading Contest, Week 4: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
Title: Welcome to Week Four of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
Text: To participate, submit your response here by July 8 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 19.

Date: Gray walls, books and a Lenin monument: A look inside the lockup where Griner has been held.
Title: The detention facility just outside Moscow where Brittney Griner, the American basketball star, has been held is a former orphanage rebuilt a decade ago to house women jailed before trial and, separately, women serving their prison sentences.
Text: At least one other well-known foreigner has spent time there: Naama Issachar, the Israeli-American arrested in April 2019 when the Russian police said they had found marijuana in her luggage.

Date: The Kremlin rejects the suggestion that Griner’s case is politically motivated.
Title: As the U.S. basketball star Brittney Griner appeared in a Russian court, the Kremlin denied on Friday that the drug charges against her were politically motivated.

Date: Labeled a ‘Challenge’ by NATO, China Signals Its Own Hard-Line Worldview
Title: When NATO put forward a new blueprint for the future this week, the alliance did not mince words on China.
Text: The alliance’s forceful declaration in its mission statement reinforced Beijing’s belief that hostile powers are bent on hobbling the country’s ascent.

Date: Tunisia’s President Drafts Constitution Giving Himself Broad Powers
Title: Tunisia’s president has taken another major step toward dismantling the country’s young democracy in a newly released draft constitution, giving himself broad powers while diluting those of Parliament and the judiciary.
Text: The proposal, which will be put to a national referendum on July 25, would enshrine the significant steps he has taken over the past year to dismantle the North African nation’s young democracy.

Date: Brittney Griner’s case in Russia appears to be the latest example of ‘hostage diplomacy.’
Title: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. athlete facing drug charges in Russia as Moscow presses ahead with its war in Ukraine, may be merely the latest victim of a practice so common it has its own name: hostage diplomacy.

Date: London Modern and Contemporary Auctions: A Market Minus the Froth
Title: This week, while some of the world’s top tennis players were in action at Wimbledon, and war continued to rage in Ukraine, Christie’s, Sotheby’s and Phillips held their traditional summer week of marquee modern and contemporary art auctions in the British capital.
Text: $36.9 million for Monet paintings, and $52.8 million for a Francis Bacon — show that even as Britain’s share of the global art market has decreased, it’s an important player.

Date: UNESCO recognizes borscht as a Ukrainian dish in urgent need of safeguarding.
Title: It was a minor victory for Ukraine in a larger war for the country’s identity as the Russian army continues its deadly onslaught, attempting to manifest through force of arms President Vladimir V. Putin’s vision of Ukraine as part of Russia.

Date: With Climate Agenda Stalled at Home, Biden Still Hopes to Lead Abroad
Title: On his first day in office, President Biden recommitted the United States to the Paris climate agreement, noting in his inaugural address that “a cry for survival comes from the planet itself. A cry that can’t be any more desperate or any more clear.”
Text: The United States has demonstrated international leadership on climate change in the past, but recent setbacks are presenting new challenges for President Biden.

Date: Advanced U.S. Arms Make a Mark in Ukraine War, Officials Say
Title: The most advanced weapons that the United States has so far supplied Ukraine are making an impact in their first several days on the battlefield, destroying Russian ammunition depots and command centers, American and Ukrainian officials say.
Text: The powerful and highly mobile weapons systems, which can fire guided rockets with a range of 40 miles, are desperately needed in the battle for eastern Ukraine.

Date: Why Is There So Much Turmoil in Eastern Congo?
Title: At its worst point, it was labeled Africa’s World War, a transnational conflict that cost millions of people’s lives. At best over the past decades, there has been a fragile peace. But there has never been a definitive end to the conflict in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
Text: More than 120 militia groups are wreaking terror in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which now accuses neighboring Rwanda of backing one particularly violent group.

Date: Corruption in Ukraine
Title: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Text: We talk to former U.S. ambassador Marie Yovanovitch about the challenges ahead.

Date: Where Does the Climate Movement Go Next?
Title: The year was 1989. Al Gore was writing about countries that now no longer exist and world leaders who are no longer alive. But his message was the same: “Earth’s fate is the No. 1 national security issue.”
Text: Al Gore weighs in on the Supreme Court’s recent ruling against the Environmental Protection Agency and explains why climate change is a “crisis of American democracy.”

Date: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
Title: His forehead cut from his rescue efforts in the rubble of a hotel in this sleepy southern resort town, Oleksandr Mararenko carried out the bodies of a woman and child early Friday morning after a Russian missile attack.
Text: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.

Date: From Star Athlete to Political Pawn: Griner Goes on Trial in Russia
Title: a potential bargaining chip in Russia’s tense standoff with the West over the war in Ukraine, described by supporters as a hostage of the Kremlin.
Text: The American basketball star Brittney Griner has endured months in a Russian prison and the threat of years more, a wartime bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.

Date: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
Title: The Biden administration announced its plan for oil and gas drilling off the coasts of the United States, closing off the possibility of new leases in the Atlantic, Pacific and Arctic Oceans but potentially allowing new lease sales in both the Gulf of Mexico and in Cook Inlet in Alaska.
Text: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.

Date: Is There Anything Funny About the War in Ukraine?
Title: Some morsels of news are so grim and absurd that they sound like they were conceived in the warped imagination of bored satirists. Like the headline from Belarus a few weeks ago, reporting that 10th graders there were being taught how to aim rifles — using shovels.
Text: At the Cultural Defense shows in Lviv, comedians and audiences look for humor amid a deadly conflict. Don’t mind the air raid alarms.

Date: Russia Detains Its Olympic Goalie, Who Had Signed With the Philadelphia Flyers
Title: A Russian hockey player who recently signed with the Philadelphia Flyers has been detained in Russia on charges that he planned to evade military service, according to reports from Russian news outlets.
Text: Ivan Fedotov, who played for Russia’s Olympic hockey team, was accused of planning to evade military service, according to Russian news reports.

Date: Iga Swiatek, a World No. 1, Gets Comfortable Using Her Clout
Title: Iga Swiatek, cap still pulled low after her latest victory, was sitting in a players café perched high above the All England Club and the grass she is still learning to love.
Text: “It’s a new position that I’m in, and I’m trying to use it the best way possible,” Swiatek said. She announced an exhibition match to help raise money for young Ukrainians.

Date: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
Title: Yurii Brukhal, an electrician by trade, did not have a very dangerous role when he volunteered for Ukraine’s territorial defense forces at the start of the war. He was assigned to make deliveries and staff a checkpoint in the relative safety of his sleepy village.
Text: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.

Date: Inflation Is Posing 19 Problems for One Central Bank
Title: For central bankers, the world has changed abruptly. After more than a decade of low inflation and interest rates, policymakers are now in an environment of high inflation, where there isn’t time for ponderous decisions, only swift and decisive action.
Text: After more than a decade of worrying about low inflation, the European Central Bank is trying to tackle the problem of high inflation across the eurozone’s economies.

Date: Skyrocketing Global Fuel Prices Threaten Livelihoods and Social Stability
Title: It’s not enough. That was the message protest leaders in Ecuador delivered to the country’s president this past week after he said he would lower the price of both regular gas and diesel by 10 cents in response to riotous demonstrations over soaring fuel and food prices.
Text: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.

Date: Ukraine dreams of rebuilding the world’s largest airplane. Can Richard Branson help?
Title: Four months ago, at the beginning of the war, countless Ukrainians were demoralized when they learned that the world’s largest cargo airplane, built in Ukraine, was destroyed in a fierce battle.

Date: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
Title: Since late February, when Russia began pummeling Ukraine with missiles and artillery on a scale unseen in Europe for decades, civilian deaths have been as inevitable as the Russian excuses that follow.
Text: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.

Date: Japan Swelters Through a Punishing Heat Wave
Title: Japan is enduring one of its worst heat waves on record, raising concern about potential power shortages amid surging demand, even as officials urged people to keep their air-conditioners running to ward off heat stroke.
Text: Temperatures in Tokyo surpassed 95 degrees for the eighth straight day on Saturday, a streak seen only once before since 1875.

Date: Ukraine accuses Russia of dropping white phosphorus on Snake Island after its retreat.
Title: Ukraine’s army has accused Russia of dropping incendiary white phosphorus on Snake Island on Friday, the day after Moscow’s forces retreated from the strategic rocky outcrop on the southwestern part of the Black Sea that is key to the Kremlin’s war aims.
Text: Some observers speculated that the strike was a move to destroy equipment that Russia had abandoned on the island and to complicate any future Ukrainian presence there.

Date: Ukrainian students are hopeful and defiant as they graduate amid war.

Text: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.

Date: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
Title: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. athlete facing criminal drug charges in Russia, may be merely the latest victim of a practice so common it has its own name: hostage diplomacy.

Date: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.

Date: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Residential Targets
Title: An attack on a shopping mall on Monday, killing 19 civilians. A missile strike on a sleepy resort town on Friday, claiming the lives of at least 21 residents. Cluster bombs on Saturday hit a residential block in an industrial hub, leaving four dead.
Text: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.

Date: Ukraine’s Lesia Tsurenko Plays Tennis for the Money
Title: Lesia Tsurenko’s Wimbledon campaign ended Friday during a match in which her head was someplace else.
Text: She used to compete because she loved tennis, but now Tsurenko wants to win as much prize money as possible to help people in her war-torn country.

Date: The fight for the last city in Luhansk under Ukrainian control reaches a pivotal point.
Title: Ukraine appeared to be pulling some troops and equipment out of Lysychansk as Russia-allied forces said Saturday that they had advanced to the center of the strategic city in eastern Ukraine after days of heavy fighting, according to Russian state media and interviews with Ukrainian troops.

Date: In City Where ‘Europe Starts,’ Ethnic Russians Start Questioning Putin’s War
Title: Like many of the ethnic Russians who live along Estonia’s eastern border with Russia, Stanislava Larchenko could not believe that President Vladimir V. Putin had gone on a killing spree in Ukraine.
Text: Narva, in northeastern Estonia, is the E.U.’s most ethnically Russian city, with a population supportive of President Vladimir Putin. But the conflict in Ukraine has set off a “mental war” between old and young.

Date: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
Title: Four men tugged at long strips of fabric to lift a coffin out of the gaping hole in the backyard of a small house. They flung the lid open to reveal the moldy corpse of Oleksiy Ketler, who had been killed instantly by shrapnel when a mortar fell on the road in Koropy, a village outside Kharkiv in northeastern Ukraine, in March.
Text: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.

Date: Four killed after explosions in a Russian city near the Ukraine border.
Title: Explosions hit the center of a Russian city just north of Ukraine early Sunday, killing four, officials said, in the deadliest known episode affecting civilians in Russia since the start of the war.
Text: The Russians said its air-defense systems shot down three missiles, but one fell to the ground in central Belgorod.

Date: How a Military Base in Illinois Helps Keep Weapons Flowing to Ukraine
Title: In a room dimly lit by television screens, dozens of airmen tapped away at computers and worked the phones. Some were keeping watch over a high-priority mission to move a Russian-made Mi-17 helicopter from a base in Arizona to a destination near Ukraine’s border.
Text: Thousands of logisticians are responsible for making sure that U.S. military aid reaches its destination, on planes, trains and ships.

Date: An American’s Murky Path From Russian Propagandist to Jan. 6
Title: In security footage from Jan. 6, it is easy to overlook the thin man wearing a red Trump hat who filters into the U.S. Capitol Building to record the mayhem with his phone.
Text: Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a “political refugee.”

Date: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
Title: Every day, Viktoriya has to walk past the house where she was raped by a Russian soldier the same age as her teenage son.
Text: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.

Date: Russia appears to be taking steps toward two industrial cities.
Title: Russia’s capture of the strategic city of Lysychansk means the front line in Ukraine’s east will shift as Russian forces regroup before pushing further south and west, military analysts and Ukrainian officers said Sunday, ensuring that the next phase of the battle will be just as bloody as the last.

Date: The eastern city of Lysychansk is a big prize for Putin.
Title: Russia’s complete control of the Ukrainian city of Lysychansk appears to be a foregone conclusion: Soviet flags are flying in the center and Ukrainian troops have withdrawn.
Text: Controlling the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk means Russia could position its forces to mount offensives on cities to the southwest.

Date: Amid Ukraine War, Orchestras Rethink ‘1812 Overture,’ a July 4 Rite
Title: With its earsplitting rounds of cannon fire and triumphal spirit, Tchaikovsky’s “1812 Overture” has been a staple of Fourth of July festivities across the United States for decades, serving as a rousing prelude to glittering displays of fireworks.
Text: Some ensembles have decided not to perform Tchaikovsky’s overture, written as commemoration of Russia’s defeat of Napoleon’s army.

Date: At the Met, Protest and Poetry About Water
Title: In a transfixing two-minute video called “River (The Water Serpent)” in the Metropolitan Museum’s American Wing we see a drone shot of a snow-flecked landscape where a crowd has gathered. Each of its members holds a vertical mirrored panel. Together, on cue, they place the panels horizontally over their heads, reflective side skyward, and begin a procession. At first, it’s loose and tidally pooling and eddying. Then it tightens into a stream of light, gains velocity, and spirals like a whirlpool.
Text: As climate change and government actions lead to water scarcity and desecration, Native American artists send an urgent message.

Date: As City Falls, Ukraine’s Last Hope in Luhansk Falls With It
Title: The last major city held by Ukraine in the heavily contested eastern province of Luhansk has fallen, military officials on both sides said Sunday, giving Moscow a milestone victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, the mineral-rich region bordering Russia that has long been in President Vladimir V. Putin’s sights.
Text: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.

Date: Australia’s new prime minister promises increased aid during visit to Ukraine.
Title: The new prime minister of Australia, Anthony Albanese, promised more military aid and more sanctions against Russia during a visit to Ukraine on Sunday that signaled continued resolve by liberal democracies to support Ukraine’s effort to rebut the Russian invasion.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.

Date: Jannik Sinner Beats Carlos Alcaraz in a Match Befitting the Stage

Text: The young talents made their Centre Court debuts hours after Wimbledon celebrated the main stage’s 100th anniversary, and they provided a foil to a contentious match the day before.

Date: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
Title: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could spark a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.
Text: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.

Date: The Mother of Strange Fashion

Text: A new exhibition in Paris on the designer Elsa Schiaparelli shows how her Surrealist “little jokes” still inspire weirdness today.

Date: Jewelers Court the Superrich, and It Seems to Pay Off
Title: After a year of exceptional growth at Chanel, the company’s global chief financial officer, Philippe Blondiaux, said in a recent interview with a news site, the Business of Fashion, that Chanel would open an unspecified number of exclusive V.I.P. stores in Asia next year to supplement its existing global network of 250 boutiques.
Text: Luxury brands double down in a strategic shift toward the biggest of the big spenders.

Date: Ukrainian Jewelers Determined to Do More Than Survive

Date: Macron Adjusts His Cabinet, Seeking a Fresh Start

Date: A spate of arrests suggests the Kremlin is further clamping down on dissent.
Title: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.

Date: Germany Posts First Monthly Trade Deficit in 30 Years
Title: For the first time in more than three decades, Germany has posted a monthly trade deficit, the most recent sign that Europe’s largest economy is facing stress because of interrupted supply chains and record energy prices linked to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

Date: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
Title: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.
